loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 33 years old and married with three children. For the last six years, she has sold material and ready-made clothes near Nairobi’s town center in Gikomba. She is requesting a loan for 80,000 Kenyan shillings to increase her inventory.

She describes herself as hardworking and says that since she joined Faulu, her business has expanded from a small retail store to a large-scale business. She added that she has also learned to save. In the future, she hopes to improve her family's standard of living and own her own business premises.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable micro-finance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add stock of fabric and clothes

loans.name: Phat

texts.en: Mrs. Phat E. lives in Prey Meas village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Yim Sarim, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice. Although they try to work hard, they still do not earn enough income to support their household, so Mrs. Phat E. has decided to ask for a loan, with which she will buy a cow to raise. She hopes to improve their living conditions by selling the cow. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others attend the local school. Her husband is shown on the right side of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Khuon

texts.en:
Mr. Khuon H. is 78 years old and a resident of Pursat Province, where he has established a small family home and earns a living as a local farmer. He is married to Mrs. Nhem Ra, age 56, who works with him in the farming business. This couple has four married and two school-aged children. 

Due to the coming dry season, which is when conditions are good for planting rice, Khuon H. has requested a Kiva loan in order to buy fertilizers and rice seed to grow on his own farmland. 

Note: Mr. Khuon H.'s wife is pictured in their farm field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and rice seed to grow on his own farmland

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more ingredients for her café business

loans.name: Kei

texts.en: Mrs. Kei U. is a villager in Deom Rum Del village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 2 hectares of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. On her plantation, she faces an obstacle because her land is infertile and has a lot of insects that affect her crops. In order to deal with these problems, she decided to ask for a loan to bU. fertilizer and pesticides, and she will use the rest of the money to purchase fuel to run the plow for the business of her husband, Mr. Morn Meth. Mrs. Kei U. has two children who are too young to work or study because they are aged one and three years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides, and fuel to run a plow.

loans.name: Purevdagva

texts.en:
G. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and two youngest children in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. The family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son lives and works in Korea and the younger two sons both attend university. G.’s husband is a carpenter who makes a variety of wooden products and she operates a grocery business in town. G. began her general store business in 1990 with working capital of 10,000 tugrugs (~7 USD). After years of hard work and diligence, she has managed to increase her working capital to 150,000 tugrugs (~105 USD). She says, “All I want is to help my children lead happy lives.” G. is requesting an 800,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase goods for her business and wood for her husband’s business. About XacBank:
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase goods for her general store and wood for her husband’s carpentry business

loans.name: Chann

texts.en: Mrs. Chann S. is a farmer in the Tuol Pong Ro village in Takeo province. She owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. In her farming, she faces a problem because her field is infertile, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to stimulate growth on her field.  She will use the rest of the loan to buy more pesticide to kill insects. Her husband, Mr. Thun Mab--on the right of the photo--is a duck breeder. Mrs. Chann S. has three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is staying at home because this child is only four years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to stimulate growth on her rice field.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Mrs. Bun C. is a villager in Srae Beong village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.  She has a problem with this farming because her rice field has infertile soil, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field.

Her husband, Mr. Leoun Sareth, helps her with the farming. Mrs. Bun C. is a mother of two children who are too young to work or study because they are two and five years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to support the field.

loans.name: Chanra

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanra S. lives in Prey Melong Thboung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Ung Pon, is a pig breeder. Since his breeding business is doing well, he wants to expand it.

So Mrs. Chanra S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and food for her husband's breeding. She has two children who are too young to work or study because they are at the ages of three and five years old. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and food.

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en: Carolyne is 24 years old and married with two young sons, aged 4 and 6. She has been selling fruit in her shop for four months and previously had a tailoring business. She is requesting Kes 10,000 to purchase Irish potatoes to begin selling chips (French fries). Carolyne says that she is optimistic that she will have a better life and has learnt the importance of saving since joining Faulu. She hopes she can continue to expand her business to improve her family's standard of living. About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To start a new French fries business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to earn income

loans.name: Di

texts.en: Mr. Di S. is a 53-year-old farmer who lives in Pursat Province. Di S. is married to Kam Khim, age 50. This couple, who work together in the farming business, has given birth to six children: two of the children are married and four are single. Due to the coming harvesting season, Di S. wants to have a cultivating machine to provide a tapping rice service for other farmers. As he lacks money to buy one, Di S. has decided to request a loan from Kiva. Di S. will use these funds to buy a machine to begin providing his service.

loans.use: To buy a machine to begin providing rice harvesting service.

loans.name: Chroeb

texts.en:
Mrs. Chroeb M. lives in Kraing Touch village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land she uses to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Khun Kheng, is a duck breeder. He is on the left of the photo.

Since his poultry business is doing well, Mrs. Chroeb M.’s husband wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Chroeb M. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks and duck food for her husband business.

Mrs. Chroeb M. has four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more ducks and duck food for her husband's business

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: S. is 29-year-old married man and father. He lives with his family members in his own small family home in Pursat Province. He owns a piece of land that he inherited from his grandmother on which he grows different kinds of crops. These crops, such as cabbages, cucumbers, and morning glories, he sells to buyers every two or three months when the plants mature. His wife has grown these crops with him. The couple is married and has two school-aged children. S. needs a loan to buy a cow and other farming supplies for his business.

loans.use: To buy more farming supplies for his business.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 46 years old and married with two adult daughters. She sells new clothing and material. She has been in this business for two years. Previously, she prepared food to sell at Gikomba Market. She is requesting a loan for KES 20,000, which she sill use to increase her inventory.

Since joining Faulu, Lucy says that she has learned about business planning and management. She describes herself as aggressive and would like to move her business to a larger location, in the centre of town, in the future. Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add stock of fabric & new clothes.

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en: Cecelia A. is married and has three children. She has no educational background. Cecelia sells smoked fish at Elmina near Aish, which she has been doing since 2002. Her husband is a fisherman. Cecelia uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Cecelia will use the loan to buy more fish to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Cecelia plans to save towards building her own house and to reinvest.

loans.use: Cecelia will use the loan to buy more fish for sale.

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en: Svetlana is married and has two children. She sells women's clothing at the central market in Belaya Tserkov town. Svetlana has been in this business for 5 years. She is a very lively, enthusiastic and hard working person. She has good knowledge of her products and provides great client service. She enjoys her sales business and wants to expand it more. This year, Svetlana gave birth to her second child and today her family needs extra income. Svetlana would like to borrow 15,000 UAH in order to purchase winter inventories. She hopes to increase her sales and to receive additional income for her family’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase winter inventory of clothing.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A. is married and has five dependents. She has no educational background. Elizabeth sells smoked fish at Elmina near Aish, which she has been doing since 1990. Her husband is a fisherman. Elizabeth uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Elizabeth will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to smoke for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth plans to save and reinvest.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish to smoke for resale.

loans.name: Vin's Group

texts.en:
There are four low-income women who have jointly taken this group loan. The group leader, Mrs. C. T., is a 34-year-old chef for a local garment factory. Her husband is a teacher for a local public school. The couple has been blessed with three school-aged children, who live in the family home. C. T. has applied for a loan to purchase pigs to raise in the pigpen next to her house. The other borrowers are:
S., a basket weaver, is asking for a loan to buy more raw materials. 
V. is taking out her loan to order baskets to sell for income.
M. is a basket maker who requests a loan to buy bamboo for weaving baskets.

loans.use: To purchase pigs to raise in the pigpen next to her house.

loans.name: Muong

texts.en: Muong S., 30 years old, lives with her family in the province of Kampong Chhnang in Cambodia. Her husband is a fisherman and they have three teenaged children. For over two years, she has been working in the rice trade business, collecting rice from farmers and re-selling it to earn income. She currently earns an average of $5 per day. Muong S. believes her investment is doing well because she is gaining more regular customers. This business is Muong S.'s main source of stable income for the family. In order to continue improving the business, Muong S. is asking for a loan to buy additional rice to sell in the future.

loans.use: To buy additional rice to sell in the future.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana D. sells smoked fish at Elmina near Bantama. Juliana has received education to the senior high level. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a fisherman. Juliana has been selling smoked fish since 2001. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more fish to process (smoke) for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards building a house. 

To smoke her fish, she goes to the seashore to buy fresh fish from the fishermen. She brings the fish home, cleans or dresses them and drains the water that comes about as a result of washing the fish. She prepares her traditionally made oven with firewood to smoke her fish for resale.

loans.use: To buy more fish to process (smoke) for sale.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a mother of 3 and she is 45 years old. Esther sells food items at retail prices within her community in Lagos state, Nigeria. She puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profit during and after the season. Esther hopes for a loan amount of 70,000 NGN to purchase more inventory to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food items to sell.

loans.name: Chaimehen

texts.en:
N. is 31 years old and lives with his wife and two young children in the Hovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest child attends kindergarten while the youngest one stays home. N. and his wife operate a retail clothing business in their town. He is responsible for importing the products from China twice a month while his wife is responsible for selling the products in the market. He began his business in 2001 and attributes his success to his good business sense and accounting skills. In order to supplement their earnings, the family also preserves vegetables in the fall and sells them in the spring when prices for such goods rise. N. is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more products from China which he can sell in his market. About XacBank:
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To purchase more products from China which he can sell in his market

loans.name: Sakomah Group

texts.en:
This is the Sakomah Group, made up of Memuna K., Kadiatu C., Yeabu K., Sallay K., and Niamatu T.. They are seeking a loan of 2.5 million LE from SMT (a partner of Shine On Sierra Leone, Waterloo) and Kiva lenders.

Memuna (second from left) is the group’s leader, and she owns a bar and restaurant where she sells drinks and food such as fried chicken and shwarmas (sandwich-like wraps of shaved meats).

Memuna is 43 and is married to a retired army major, and together they have two children, both of whom are currently attending secondary school.

Memuna has been working in the restaurant business since the age of 12. Twenty years ago, she opened her own, and now she is seeking a loan so that she can expand the stock of drinks she keeps on hand.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for her restaurant

loans.name: Tamaranesu Group

texts.en:
The Tamaranesu Group is made up of Zainab K., Kadiatu C., Isatu K., and Fatmata S.. Zainab (second from right) is the group’s leader.

For the past fifteen years Zainab has owned a stand that sells staple foods such as palm oil and already-cooked rice. She is married to a retired architect and has four children who attend primary and secondary schools.

The group is seeking a loan of 2 million LE from Kiva lenders and SMT (a partner of Shine On Sierra Leone, Waterloo). With her share, Zainab plans to buy more bagged rice which can be cooked and sold from her market stall.

loans.use: To buy an additional stock of bagged rice

loans.name: Mujidat

texts.en:
Mujidat loves cooking and that is why she sells cooked foods by hawking the food from one market to another within her community in Lagos, Nigeria.

Mujidat is married with three children. She is 30 years old and is a focused hard-worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.

Mujidat hopes for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: To Time Group

texts.en:
Meet Kadieyatu B., Mohamed K. and Adama K., the three members of the To Time Group. They are seeking a loan of 1.4 million LE from SMT (a partner of Shine On Sierra Leone, Waterloo) and Kiva lenders in order to invest in their respective businesses.

Kadieyatu is the group’s leader, and she is married to a carpenter with whom she has three children. For the past twelve years she has sold a variety of materials including palm oil, wood, and soap. Recently, Kadieyatu constructed a store from which she hopes to start selling building materials. She is planning to use her portion of the loan in order to purchase her starting inventory.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her new store

loans.name: The United Brothers Group

texts.en:
Francis K. K., Steven M. and Daddy S. call themselves The United Brothers Group. They are three enterprising men from Sierra Leone who are joining together to seek their second loan through SMT (a partner of Shine On Sierra Leone, Waterloo). They are requesting a loan of 3 million LE with the help of Kiva lenders.

Francis is the group’s leader, and he is 28 years old with a wife and two children in primary school. For nine years, Francis has worked selling spare auto parts and supplies such as engine oil, spark plugs, and brake fluid. In his time in business, he has found that certain goods (such as brake fluid) sell faster than others, and he plans to use his portion of the loan to purchase an additional stock of these “fast-moving” goods, with the hope of increasing the revenue brought in by his store.

loans.use: To purchase additional supplies of fast-selling items

loans.name: Shagdar

texts.en:
N. is a 55 year old widow who lives in the Govi-Altai province of Mongolia. All three of her children are grown and live on their own. N. lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and operates a hairdressing salon in her town. N. graduated from a hairdressing school in 1972 and, since then, has been working as a hairdresser. She has taken out loans from XacBank five times in the past and has proven herself to be a trustworthy customer who always repays on time and in full. N. is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug loan in order to replace the styling tools and equipment used in her salon. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

loans.use: To replace the styling tools and equipment used in her salon

loans.name: God Is Good Group

texts.en:
The God is Good Group is made up of Isatu C., Mariatu C., Aminata M. and Joya S.. These four women are seeking a loan of 2 million LE from SMT (a partner of Shine On Sierra Leone, Waterloo) and Kiva lenders in order to invest in their existing businesses.

Isatu (right) is the group leader. She is 48 years old and has owned a business selling a variety of household goods including palm oil, wood, and charcoal for over twenty years.

Isatu has five children who attend school. Her husband has recently fallen ill and is forced to stay home, making Isatu the primary breadwinner for the household. With her portion of the loan, she hopes to expand the inventory she holds in her stall to bring more income back to the home.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory for her business

loans.name: Let's Unite Group

texts.en:
Fatmata K., Mariama C., Fatmata K. and Marion T. have gotten together to form the Let’s Unite Group to seek their first loan from SMT (a partner of Shine On Sierra Leone, Waterloo) and Kiva lenders. They are asking for a loan of 2 million LE in order to invest in their businesses.

Fatmata K. (second from right) is the group’s leader. She is married to a soldier, and together they have seven children who are currently attending primary and secondary schools.

For fifteen years, Fatmata has owned a shop outside Freetown where she sells Sierra Leonean staple goods such as rice, palm oil, and flour. With her portion of the loan, she hopes to expand her inventory and bring some additional income into the household.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory for her business

loans.name: Women In Development Group

texts.en:
Meet Fatmata K., Fatu C., Kadiatu S. and Mariama S.. Together, they form the Women in Development loan group.

Fatmata is the group’s leader, and at 41 years of age she has been in business for over fifteen years selling bagged rice, tomatoes, palm oil, and other staple goods at a market stall about twenty miles from Freetown.

Fatmata is married to a police officer and, together, they have four children, three of whom attend school and one of whom is too young.

The Women in Development Group is seeking a loan of 1.8 million LE from SMT (a partner of Shine On Sierra Leone, Waterloo) and Kiva lenders. Fatmata plans to use her portion to buy additional supplies of palm oil and rice to sell from her stand.

loans.use: To purchase additional supplies of bagged rice and palm oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine has been selling secondhand children’s clothes for the last two years and previously sold vegetables in a kiosk. She is 33 years old and married with a young son named William. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to add an assortment of new inventory.

For the future, Catherine hopes to have a stable business so that she is able to provide for her family’s needs along with her husband. She would like to own permanent business premises and become a wholesale supplier. She describes herself as determined, committed, and persistent in her business.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a deposit-taking micro-finance company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add stock

loans.name: Bestina

texts.en:
Bestina sells foodstuffs like rice and cooking oils. She hawks her foodstuffs (goes door-to-door) within her community in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a focused and hard working woman and is so determined to lift her business and family above poverty.

Bestina is 33 years old and married with four children. Her husband is an electrician. She is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 45 years old and married with five children aged between 6 and 20. She runs a tailoring business in Nairobi, making children's plastic pants. She has had her business for five years and is requesting a loan of Kes 15,000 to purchase materials in rolls. Beatrice describes herself as hardworking, determined and consistent and hopes to become a major supplier of her products. Her dream is to be able to pay for quality education for her children. About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To purchase materials in rolls

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more cereals for her business

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria sells foodstuffs like tomato paste in her stall in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 35 years old and married with four children. She has been in this business for two years. She hopes to become a major foodstuff distributor in Lagos State.

Maria is hoping for a loan of 50,000 naira to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase beer and soft drinks for her business

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana G. is single and has one child. She has received junior high education.

Diana sells smoked fish at Elmina near Bantama, which she has been doing since 2002. She uses her income to pay school fees, utility bills and apartment bills.

Diana will use the loan to purchase more fish to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Vichanira

texts.en: Vichanira is 40 years old and married with a 14-year-old son named Kevin. She sells snacks like groundnuts (peanuts), sim sim (sesame seeds), and mandazi (similar to a doughnut). She has been in business for six years and is now requesting a loan for Kes 10,000 to increase her stock of food items. Vichanira describes herself as a hardworking and determined person who doesn't give up easily. She hopes to expand her business and supply other shops so that she can cater to her family's needs and supplement her husband's income. About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To increase her stock of food items

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya sont des femmes mariées vivant dans des foyers monogames nucléaires à Sélingué (une sous-préfecture située à 140  kilomètres de Bamako) avec en moyenne d’âge trente trois ans et trois enfants.
Elles se sont connues par des liens d’amitié et d’activités professionnelles. Ce groupe de femmes excellent dans l’achat vente d’articles divers. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe après avoir remboursé sans difficulté le précédent. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  à Sélingué et à Bamako (capitale du Mali) une fois par mois et revendent à Sélingué sur des étales ou en ambulant dans les quartiers et  des les entreprises publiques  et privées.
Elles comptent avoir avec ce prêt,  35 pagnes, 10 cartons de savons de ménage et 40  kilogrammes de matières premières pour la fabrication d’encens. Elles vendent sur le marché de Sélingué et Dalabala à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 26.000 FCFA qui permettra de  payer l’échéance du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The women of the Danaya group are married women living in nuclear monogamous homes in Sélingué (a sub-district located 140 kilometers from Bamako). On average, they are thirty three years of age and have three children. They know each other by bonds of friendship and professional activities. This group of women excells in the sale of various items. They are on their second group loan after repaying the preceding loan without difficulty. They supply themselves in Sélingué and Bamako (capital of Mali) once a month and sell to Sélingué from a place on the street, on foot in the neighborhoods and to public and private businesses. With this loan they plan to buy, 35 sheets of cloth, 10 boxes of household soap and 40 kilograms of materials for making incense. They sell in the markets of Sélingué and Dalabala to a various and varied clientele. They hope to realize a monthly profit of 26,000 FCFA that will allow them to repay the loan and contribute to the family expenditures.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth, soap and materials for making incense.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes M. is single and has three children. She has received junior high school education. Agnes sells smoked fish at Elmina near Bantama, which she has been doing since 2000. She uses her income to pay school fees, utility bills and apartment rent.

Agnes will use the loan to buy fish for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Agnes plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase an additional stock of household products

loans.name: Dupe

texts.en:
Dupe sells drinks, chemicals and insecticides in her stall. She puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. Dupe has been in business for nine years. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. Dupe is happily married with five children and she is 48 years old. She hopes to be a major drink distributor in Lagos State in the future. She is a LAPO member. She is hoping for a loan of 150,000 naira to purchase more drinks and insecticides to sell. 
She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and insecticides to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She is a 51-year-old single mother of two children, ages 19 and 23 years old. Both her children go to school. She rents a one-room house where she lives with the three people in her family. Florence also takes care of additional family members. They have access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent for her residence and business premises, school fees for her children and food for the family.

Florence works seven days a week. On average, she receives 20 customers a day. She incurs transport costs to and from her suppliers in Owino market (one of the busiest markets in Uganda). She sells retail to all kinds of people. Florence has been in her business for seven years and with MCDT for five years, now on her 20th loan. Florence aspires to grow her business and to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica D. sells sweet apples and fresh fish in Elmina near Bantama. She is single and has two children. Monica has completed senior high school. She has been selling sweet apples and fish since 2005. She is responsible for payments on her apartment, utility bills and the school fees of her children. Her loan will be used to buy more fish to sell. She hopes to save the profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase supplies for a cafe

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a 33-year-old mother of three. She runs a retail business selling dry foods and cereals at Kamuuani market in Machakos. She also earns extra income by running a grocery shop in the same location. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 KES to add to her stock of dry foods and cereals. She employs one person in her successful business.

About Faulu Kenya
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add to her stock of dry foods and cereals

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en:
Titilayo is 40 years old and married with three children. She sells hair extensions, hair relaxer, and drinks at retail prices, and she is also a hair stylist. She has been in this business for a long time. Most of the challenges she faces in her business are to do with the very high transport costs to the market.

This is the high season for Titilayo's business and she hopes to meet her customers' requirements. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions and drinks to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 27-year-old single mother. She has a seven-year-old child who goes to school, and she also takes care of additional family members. She rents a two-roomed house where she lives with two people, and has access to electricity and piped water.

Joyce works seven days a week. She sells food and other items to all sorts of people and, on average, receives 20 customers a day. Her residence works as her business premises. She incurs additional transport costs traveling to and from Nakawa market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda.

Joyce has been in this business for five years, and has also been with Kiva partner MCDT for five years. She is now servicing her twentieth loan. Her monthly expenses include rent for her residence and business premises, school fees for her child, and food for her family. Joyce wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar and rice, boxes of soap, and cartons of salt. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and hopes to start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar and rice, cartons of salt, and boxes of soap

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica G. is single and has one child. She has been through junior high school. Veronica sells smoked fish at Elmina near Bantama, which she has been doing since 1999. Veronica uses her income to pay for her apartment, the utility bills and the school fees of her child. Veronica will use the loan to buy more fish to process (smoke) for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Veronica plans to save to build a house.

loans.use: Veronica will use the loan to buy more fish to process (smoke) for sale.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 37-year-old married father of five. He owns a timber yard in the Kyumbi area of Machakos where he sells timber. He also earns extra income by running a hardware shop next to the timber yard. Stephen is requesting a third loan of Kes 80,000 to add a stock of timber to his business. He describes the business environment in which he operates as very busy and employs three employees. About Faulu Kenya: Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add to his stock of timber

loans.name: Moriamo

texts.en:
Moriamo sells children’s clothes and sarongs and has been in this business for a long time. She is married with three children and she is 39 years old. She hopes to give her children a quality education so that they can become graduates. She is a hardworking woman and she uses her hard work to ensure that there is food on her table for her immediate family members.

This is the high season for her sales and the demands for her goods are high. She hopes for a loan of N150,000 to purchase more children’s clothes and sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders. She hopes to own a boutique in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more children's clothes and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Aisa

texts.en: Aisa sells fruit like apples at wholesale and retail prices to customers from her stall. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 49 years old and married with five children. She hopes to be a major distributor of fruits in Lagos. She has been in her business for a long time. She is very dedicated to this business and is trying to sustain it. Aisa is hoping for a loan 150,000 naira to buy more fruit to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to sell

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity owns a restaurant in Naguru and works seven days a week. She is a 38-year-old single mother of four children ranging in age from 11 to 17 years old. Charity also takes care of additional family members. All her children go to school. She owns a two-room house where she lives with five people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent for her business premises, school fees for her children and food for the family. Her business premises works as her residence.

Charity wants to use this loan to buy more bags of rice, bunches of bananas and cooking oil. She wants to see her business grow and hopes to start another restaurant near Makerere University Business School. She has transport costs to and from her suppliers in Nakawa market (one of the busiest markets in Uganda). She sells retail to all kinds of people. On average, she serves 40 customers a day. Charity has been in her business for over ten years and with MCDT for five years, now on her 20th loan.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of  rice, bunches of bananas and cooking oil

loans.name: Aderunke

texts.en: Aderunke sells jewelry and ice blocks from home; she makes more profit from the ice block business. To her great joy, the high season is here. She is happy because her sales will increase. Aderunke has been in her business for a long time. She is 33 years old and married with three children. She has been borrowing from LAPO for the past three years and loans have been the source of capital for her business. She is hoping for a loan of 100,000 naira to purchase more ice blocks and jewelry to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more ice blocks and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent M. is 37 years old and married. For the past six years, he has run a retail shop selling household items, foodstuffs, kerosene and other products. 

He is requesting a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to purchase more kerosene from the depot. He describes himself as valiant and ambitious. He hopes to expand his business so that, in the future, he can own his own house.  

About Faulu Kenya
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add to his stock of kerosene.

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina K. is single and has three children. She sells various agricultural products such as seeds and fertilizer. Her income is about 4,000 Ukrainian grivna (UAH).

Galina has been in this business for 10 years. She used to go to Russia to make her living, but it was difficult for her family. That is why Galina decided to try her own business. She rented a kiosk at a good location and began her sales business. Galina was able to create a good pricing policy that attracted new clients and kept returning clients. Galina's business grew, and today it is the only source of her income.

Galina would like to borrow 10,000 UAH to purchase fertilizer. Her goal is to increase sales and make additional income.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for resale.

loans.name: Allakabo Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Allakabo sont des femmes mariées vivant en général dans des foyers polygames traditionnels avec une moyenne d’âge de trente quatre  ans et ayant en moyenne quatre  enfants. Elles résident à Kéléya, (dans la préfecture de Bougouni) à 100  kilomètres de Bamako (la capitale du Mali).
Elles se sont connues par des liens de famille et de voisinage et font des activités de commerce d’articles divers. 
Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso et tous les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés. 
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt, 10 cartons de savon de ménage, 8 chargements de bois de chauffe, 60  kilogrammes de divers condiments alimentaires et 120  kilogrammes de divers fruits.
Elles s’approvisionnent deux fois par mois sur les marchés de Kéléya et environnants et revendent à Kéléya sur des étales ou en ambulant en détail, au comptant et rarement à crédit à une clientèle riche et variée.
Elles espèrent réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 22. 000  FCFA qui servira à payer l’échéance du prêt et subvenir aux besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
The women of the Allakabo group are married women, usually living in traditional polygamous homes. On average they are thirty four years of age and have four children. They reside in Kéléya, (in the prefecture of Bougouni) about 100 kilometers from Bamako (the capital of the Mali). They know each other by bonds of family and neighborhood and are involved in the sale of various items. They are on their fourth loan with Soro Yiriwaso and all the previous loans were well reimbursed. With this loan they plan to buy 10 boxes of household soap, 8 loads of wood for heating, 60 kilograms of various food condiments and 120 kilograms of various fruit. They supply themselves two times a month in the markets of Kéléya and surrounding areas and sell to Kéléya from street locations or on foot, usually for cash and occasionally for credit to a rich and varied clientele. With this loan they hope to realize an average monthly profit of 22,000 FCFA that will serve to repay the loan and provide for the family needs.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various articles for resale such as soap, wood, fruit, etc.

loans.name: Mujeres En Desarrollo 2 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Maximo is a 42-year-old borrower who lives near San Pedro D. Macorís, Dominican Republic. He is the coordinator for his group, Mujeres en Desarrollo (Women in Development), and his story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Specifically, Maximo and his fellow borrowers live in Batey Margarita. Bateyes are small, rural communities built by sugar companies for their field workers. Bateyes are isolated, have no running water, and have unreliable electricity at best. Maximo lives with his wife and four children, the youngest of whom is six years old. This is Maximo’s sixth loan with Esperanza International.

Maximo runs a successful colmado, which is the local version of a small general store. With his loan, he plans to buy foods such as rice, beans, flour, and oil, as well as gasoline and some clothing to sell to his community. He is slowly expanding his business and offering more products to his customers as each new loan comes in. Maximo knows that even though his loans may be small, little by little he is improving the life of his business, his own life, and his family’s lives. Thank you for lending to Maximo and the Mujeres en Desarrollo group!

loans.use: To purchase rice, beans, clothing, and gasoline for resale.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth sells bags of cement to make a living. She puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. She is a friendly woman and she uses this skill to attract more customers to her shop. One of her challenges is competitors that she hopes to outsmart when she purchases more bags of cement. She is happily married with six children, and she is 43 years old. She is hoping for a loan of 80,000 naira to purchase more bags of cement to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of cement to sell

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr: Aminata F. est une ancienne sociétaire de la caisse de Baye Laye .C’est une dame de 45 ans qui habite a Wakhinane a Guediawaye.Son mari est menuisier et elle est mère de six enfants dont l’âge varie entre huit et vingt sept ans. Concernant son activité, elle est orientée dans le domaine du commerce. Elle a commence a fréquenté  le marche DIOLA avec l’ancien bateau LE JOOLA ou elle achetait des poissons séchés  des balais et de l’huile de palme. Cependant  elle a opte pour la diversification de son commerce. Ainsi  selon la période  elle se lance aussi dans la vente de tissus de thiouraye ,de parfums pour homme, de déodorants  de chambre. Elle emprunte 100 000 frs. L’objet de son crédit est l’achat d’huile de palme, de balais et de thiouraye pour renouveler son stock. Les profits tires de son activité  lui permettent d’être  indépendante   de son mari et de satisfaire les besoins de ses enfants. Elle est très  habituée a son commerce et sa deuxième  attente est de renforcer son épargne. Son souhait est de pouvoir voyager dans le futur pour acheter des marchandises maximiser ses  bénéfices  et parvenir a avoir sa propre maison.
texts.en:
Aminata F. is a former associate of the Gapes Laye communal bank. she is a lady of 45 years that lives in Wakhinane a Guediawaye. Her husband is a carpenter. She is the mother of six children , whose ages vary between eight and twenty seven years. Concerning his activity, she is dedicated to sales. She began frequenting the DIOLA market with the old boat THE JOOLA, where she bought dried fish, straw and palm oil. Consequently she has choosen to diversify her business. Over time she has added the sale of thiouraye (a special perfume), perfumes for men, and room deodorizer. She would like to borrow 100,000 frs. The purpose of this loan is to buy palm oil, straw and thiouraye to renew her stock. The profits earned from this activity allow her to be independent of her husband and to satisfy the needs of her children. She is very experienced at her business and her second hope is to grow her savings. In the future, she hopes to be able to travel to buy the merchandise, maximize her profits and be able to have her own house.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy straw, palm oil and perfume for resale.

loans.name: Oluwatoyin

texts.en:
Oluwatoyin sells kerosene at wholesale and retail prices to her customers, both within and outside her community in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has five tanks that she uses to store kerosene to sell. She has been in this business for a long time.

Oluwatoyin is the mother of five children and she is 44 years old. All her children are in school and she hopes to give them quality education. That is why she puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. Oluwatoyin is hoping for a loan of 150,000 naira to purchase more kerosene to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a 25-year-old businessman. He repairs electronics like radios and watches in Huruma estate in Nairobi. He also earns extra income through the sale of scrap metal. He says that his business is located along a busy road and this is a good location for business. He is requesting his first loan of 15,000 Kenyan shillings to boost his business. He hopes to own a stable electronics business and improve the living standards of his family. He describes himself as ambitious, hardworking and determined.

Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a deposit-taking microfinance company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To boost an electronics business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of cereals for her business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is married with 4 children and she is advanced in age. She is 55 years old. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells local gin popularly known as "ogogoro" in Nigeria.

She is a hard working woman and she hopes to lift her business and family above poverty.  She is very happy with the loan facilities she is receiving from Kiva. She hopes for a loan amount of N 140,000 to purchase more local gin to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more local gin to sell

loans.name: C2255 Abadacogora Group

texts.en:
Josephine M. is 32 years old, married with four children, and she also takes care of four dependents. She is the president of a group called Abadacogora, which operates the business of selling secondhand clothes in the Gasabo district, not far from the center of Kigali. The hours of their business are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

This group has been in business for three years and has proven itself as a viable entity! They are requesting their first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their business through purchasing more bales of clothes. They hope this will increase their monthly sales of clothing to more customers which will hopefully bring them more profit. As the business grows and strengthens they hope, simply, to take better care of their families.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothing

loans.name: Mujeres En Desarrollo 3 & 5 Group

texts.en:
Felicia is a 61 year old borrower who lives near San Pedro D. Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Mujeres en Desarrollo (Women in Development), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Specifically, Felicia and her fellow borrowers live in Batey Margarita. Bateyes are small, rural communities built by sugar companies for their field workers. They are isolated, have no running water, and have unreliable electricity at best. Felicia lives with her husband and one of her grandchildren; she has seven children, but all have married and moved out of her home. 

Felicia runs a successful eatery which serves traditional Dominican foods (rice and beans, plantains, stewed chicken and beef). On the siD., she also sells clothing to add to her income. Felicia says that she really enjoys working and loves the loans she has received from Esperanza, saying that if there is anything available to help her business, she would want it.

Unsurprisingly with the work ethic she brings to the table, this is Felicia’s ninth loan overall with Esperanza International. She has a perfect repayment record so far and hopes to continue using the financial services available to her. Thank you for lending to Felicia and the Mujeres en Desarrollo group!

loans.use: Rice, beans, meat, and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her business

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Mrs. D. is from the town of Sta. Cruz, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old, is married, and is blessed with two school-aged children. Mrs. D. owns and operates a hog-raising business. She has been engaged in this business for more than six years and earns a PHP 10,000 monthly net income. She also has a monthly remittance from her husband, who is abroad, and income from her coco land. In 2006, Mrs. D. joined PMPC to access its programs and services. Recently, she's obtaining her 6th loan of PHP 25,000 which will be used as additional capital for her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her hog-raising business

loans.name: C2866 Dufatanurunana Group

texts.en:
Athanase R. is 57 years old, married with five children, and he and his wife also take care of two dependents. Athanase lives in the Gasabo district where he is the president of the group called Dufatanurunana. This group operates the business of selling a variety of goods in a well known local shop and it is open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day. All are committed to the success of the business and are excited about the possibility of being able to buy more goods to sell to attract more customers and make more sales and, hopefully, more profits as well!

This group is now requesting its first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their shop by purchasing some additional goods which will make them more competitive. If successful, they plan to build their own warehouse, pay school fees for their children, and continue to build a secure future for themselves and their families.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for their business

loans.name: Bolale

texts.en:
Bolale sells drinks, wine and juice at retail prices to her customers. The high season for her business is here. She is a hardworking woman. She loves her business because it is highly competitive. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is 35 years old and married with two children. She is hoping for a loan of 100,000 naira to purchase more drinks, wine and juice to sell. 
She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, wine and juice to sell

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith B. is from the village of Catadman, Ozamiz City. She is 44 years old, married, and has two adult and one school-aged child. Judith owns and operates a computer services business in their place. She has been engaged in this business for over one year and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month. She gladly poses at her Internet Cafe with her customers. Judith joined PMPC to gain access to financial services and to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 from MPC. Judith is requesting a new loan of 14,500 PHP which will be used to buy another computer and computer accessories like headphones, keyboards, speakers, and printers. This will be her seventh loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy another computer and accessories

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes M. is 45 years old, married with five children aged between 7 and 25 years, and she takes care of one dependent as well. Agnes lives in the Gatsibo district, approximately four hours drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

It is in this area that, since 2004, Agnes has operated her business of selling petroleum (gasoline), a much-needed household supply in Rwanda. The hours of her business require that she works from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Although Agnes has been in this business for five years, she would like a loan in order to expand her working capital which will help her to pay her suppliers and get lower rates for her products. All of this should result in increasing the profits of her business. For that to happen, she is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company.

With this business expansion, Agnes hopes to get more customers. She will will likely reinvest any potential profits in the business as well as take better care of her family's needs and begin to build a more secure future for them.

loans.use: To buy petroleum containers

loans.name: Nelfa

texts.en: Nelfa S. is from Tinago, Ozamiz City. She is 36 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Nelfa owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Nelfa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Nelfa is now requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her sixth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional products to sell

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy C. is from the city of Ozamiz. She is 25 years old, is married, and has one infant child.

Nancy owns and operates a business providing transport to local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Nancy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from PMPC.

Nancy is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in her business. This will be her third loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: To repair her motorcycle

loans.name: Carmen Rosa

texts.en:
Carmen, a single 46-year-old, runs a restaurant out of her home. She has three children. Her oldest child is married and lives on his own and the two younger children live with her. The younger children are studying at the university and, when they have free time, they help their mother with the restaurant. Carmen has been in this business for over 30 years now. The restaurant is located in a village called Villa Coromilla in the Cochabamba department of Bolivia.

With her loan, Carmen will purchase more food for her restaurant. Recently, the demand for her restaurant has been increasing and she wants to make sure that she can meet the demand. She is excited and hopeful that her earnings will increase after she invests the loan in her business.

loans.use: To purchase food for a restaurant

loans.name: Funke

texts.en:
Funke hawks sarongs of various colors and sizes at retail prices to her customers. She is 45 years old and married with five children. She is a hardworking woman and she hopes to lift her family above poverty. The high season for her business is now and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is hoping for a loan of 70,000 naira to purchase more sarongs to sell. She hopes to own a boutique in the future.
She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Bosco

texts.en:
Bosco B. is 25 years old, is single with one dependent, and he lives in Gatsibo district. Here he has had a bulk supply/household goods shop for the past five years. He is a true entrepreneur and loves having his own business. The hours of his business requires that he work from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day. He does not employ anyone else in his business - it's just Bosco.

The nature of his business is somewhat capital intensive and in order to grow, Bosco is now requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. He will use the loan in order to expand his shop through purchasing larger quantities of bulk goods and supplies at lower costs. With this additional capital, it will allow him to get the best pricing and adequately satisfy the product needs and wants of his customers.

As any entrepreneur, Bosco hopes to get more profits, which will help him to build a secure future for himself and his family (someday?!).

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of bulk goods and household goods

loans.name: Exito Con Cristo Group

texts.en:
Maria runs a small grocery store in her neighborhood. In the past, she sold mostly non-perishable or semi-perishable foods such as rice, beans, flour and oil – foods which make up Dominican staples. She is a 33-year-old borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. Maria and the other borrowers in her group live in Los Llanos, a small town to the north of San Pedro. She lives with her husband and three teenage children in a small home made of cement blocks and wooden paneling.

Before coming to Esperanza, Maria was unable to find a fair loan. With this, her first loan with Esperanza, she will expand her sales to include fruits and vegetables. In the past, it was not viable for Maria to purchase such perishable items. Now, with an increase in her cash flow, these items will bring in even more profit. She hopes that with the new income from this loan, she will be able to finish the house with cement blocks only. That way, it will be secure from thieves and safer as a shelter during hurricane season. She likes that Esperanza not only gives her a loan, but also creates community, gives lessons, and provides other banking services such as savings. She is now confident that she can send all three of her children to school through university.

Maria is the coordinator for her group, Éxito con Cristo ("Success with Christ"), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group. Thank you for lending to Maria and the Éxito con Cristo group!

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Carmencita

texts.en:
Mrs. Carmencita R., 42 years of age, is married and is a resident of Purok 3, Sangay Daku, Ozamiz City. She is blessed with five children, of whom three are now adults and are single, and the other two are of school age. Mr. Daniel R., her husband, is a farmer and he is the one cultivating their little parcel of corn land.

For twenty-one years, corn production has been the main source of their livelihood. With a little sari-sari (variety) store in their home, Carmencita also helps her husband with the family needs. At present, they are earning an average net income of not less than 5,000 PHP every six months from corn production.

Carmencita joined the PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) program of Paglaum MPC and was able to obtain our project loan for purchasing commercial fertilizer for corn production and additional capital for her sari-sari store.

Now, Carmencita is applying for 7,000 PHP as her 2nd loan. The income from this loan will be used to support the educational needs for their children and for loan repayments.

loans.use: To purchase commercial fertilizers for corn production and to use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

location.town: Purok 3 Sangay Daku, Ozamiz City, Mindanao

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase ingredients for making snacks

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena has two children. She is 38 years old. She and her husband have been dairy-cow farmers for many years. They waited several years before they began having children because Elena was in poor health. After they were able to have their first child, they felt like their lives were complete. Elena and her husband then began constructing a small mill, where her husband, Carlos, produces cattle feed for their livestock and sells the remainder at the Huaña Cahua market.

After her children overcame illnesses, Elena enrolled them in a local school. After school each day, the children help Elena and Carlos by tending to the livestock. The older child also helps Elena's husband with the mill, making cattle feed for their livestock.

With this loan, Elena hopes to grow and expand her production of cattle feed so that they can build a reputation among other livestock farmers for their great product. This way, they can increase their sales and their earnings.

loans.use: Equipment for cattle feed production

loans.name: Gleceria

texts.en: Gleceria C. is from the village of Tubod. She is 74 years old, is widowed, and has six adult children. Gleceria owns and operates a "sari-sari" store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2000, Gleceria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of from PMPC. Gleceria is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 18th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan O. is from the town of Clarin. She is 34 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Susan owns and operates a specialized retail store selling okay-okay (used clothing) in the local community. Susan has been engaged in this business for six years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In October 2009, Susan joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to buy more used clothing to sell. This will be her first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothing to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of ingredients for her business

loans.name: Seleman Clementine

texts.en:
Seleman Clementine M. is 30 years old, single, and she lives in Gatsibo district, approximately four hours drive from the capital city of Rwanda.

Seleman is a pharmacist by training and she has had a pharmacy selling a variety of medicines since 2003. She works very hard to make her business a success - a typical day starts at 6 a.m. and ends at 5 p.m. or later.

Seleman is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more variety of medicines needed by the majority of her customers. These medicines are costly but she believes that she will be able to sell them and attract new customers. If successful, this will result in greater profits, which she will likely reinvest in the business as well as take care of her children and continue to build a secure future for them.

loans.use: To buy a variety of medicines

loans.name: Ovidio

texts.es:
El señor Ovidio R. vive en casa de sus padres, en la zona  de Pasankeri, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposa, la señora Adriana Gómez y sus tres hijos.
El señor Ovidio trabaja como chofer de transporte publico y su esposa realiza costura de manteles que vende en oficinas de esta ciudad, ingresos con los que mantienen a su familia.
El crédito solicitado es para el acabado de la construcción de dos habitaciones para habitarlas y así tener espacio principalmente para sus hijos.
Esta es la cuarta vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Mr. Ovidio R. lives in his parents' house, in the zone of Pasankeri, on the west hillside of the city of La Paz, together with his wife, Mrs. Adriana Gomez, and their three children. Mr. Ovidio works as a chauffeur in public transportation and his wife sews tablecloths that she sells in offices of the city, income which supports their family. The requested credit will be used to finish the construction of 2 rooms, in order to have enough space principally for their children. This is the fourth time that they have requested a loan, and a socioeconomic analysis qualifies them favorably to access this credit.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To finish the construction of two rooms in his house for greater comfort for his children

loans.name: Wilson

texts.es:
El señor Wilson T. vive en casa de sus padres, en la zona  Llojeta de la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor Wilson es empleado en una empresa avícola de esta ciudad, ingresos con los que se mantiene y colabora con sus padres.
El crédito solicitado es para la refacción de los techos de su vivienda que se encuentran deteriorados por su antigüedad.
Esta es la primera vez que solicitan préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado los califican favorablemente y pueden acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Mr. Wilson T. lives in his parents' house, in the Llojeta zone of the City of La Paz. He is employed in a bird-raising enterprise in this city. With his income he maintains himself and collaborates with his parents.

The credit he requests is for repairing the roof of their house which, due to age, is currently in a deteriorated state.

This is the first time he has solicited a loan and the socioeconomic analysis carried out qualifies him favorably and gives him access to a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO REPAIR THE ROOF OF THEIR HOUSE

loans.name: Arturo

texts.es:
Arturo, tiene un taller donde elabora cotillones y los vende en la calle Illampu, un lugar de la ciudad de La Paz donde se comercializa productos para fiestas y eventos de todo tipo.
Vive en la zona de san pedro  de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa propia
El crédito será destinado para capital de trabajo ( compra de cartulina, papel, cola, y otros). 
Es la Décima quinta vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial lo califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de su crédito.
texts.en:
Arturo has a shop where he makes party favors. He sells them on Illampu Street, a place in the city of La Paz where products for parties and all types of events are sold. He lives in his own house in the San Pedro region of the city of La Paz The loan is to buy cardboard, paper, glue, and other things. This is the fifteenth time he has asked Impro for a loan. His history qualifies him as client 1, which means good completion of paying his loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cardboard, paper, glue, and other supplies to make party favors and piñatas.

loans.name: La Reforma 4 & 6 Group

texts.en:
Olita is a 49-year-old borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, La Reforma (Reform), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Olita and the other women in La Reforma live in Consuelo, a small town just to the north of San Pedro. Consuelo lacks any kind of reliable electricity and has no potable running water. She has six children that live with her, the youngest of whom is eight years old. In addition, Olita runs a small shop from her home, selling clothing to her neighbors and friends. Needless to say, a small house containing seven people and a business is a little cramped.

For this reason, Olita hopes to someday rent or own her own shop. This would free up quite a bit of space in her home, giving her family a more comfortable living space. With her current loan, Olita plans on purchasing more clothing to sell in her shop. This is her seventh loan with Esperanza International, and she has a perfect repayment record so far. Thank you for lending to Olita and La Reforma group!

loans.use: To purchase men's and women's clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of cereals in bulk for her business.

loans.name: Jorge

texts.es:
Jorge tiene un vehiculo que trabaja como taxi, es el único que solventa sus gastos ya que esta solo en la ciudad de La Paz, porque su familia se encuentra en la República de Argentina
Vive en la zona Pampahasi de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa de sus suegros.
El crédito será destinado para compra de llantas y mantenimiento de su vehiculo.
Es la quinta vez que solicita un crédito en Impro. Su responsabilidad y la necesidad que tiene le dan la oportunidad de obtener este crédito.
texts.en:
Jorge has a vehicle that he uses as a taxi. It is the only thing he has to pay his expenses. He is alone in the city of La Paz because his family is in the Republic of Argentina. He lives with his in-laws in the Pampahasi region of the city of La Paz. The loan is to buy tires and for maintenance of his vehicle. This is the fifth time he has asked Impro for a loan. His responsibility and the need that he has give him the opportunity to get this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tires and pay for maintenance on his taxi

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel O. repairs electronic appliances at a shop in Elmina near Abvis. Samuel has junior high education. Samuel has been repairing electrical appliances since 2006. He is responsible for paying utility bills and rent for his apartment. His loan will be used to buy spare parts, tools and copper wire for sale. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest into his business.

loans.use: His loan will be used to buy spare parts, tools and copper wire for sale.

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
Juan Carlos tiene un vehiculo que trabaja como taxi, es independiente y soltero.
Vive en la zona de Tembladerani de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa de sus padres. 
El crédito será destinado para reparación de vehiculo, y compra de llantas.
Es la tercera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial lo califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de su crédito.
texts.en:
Juan Carlos has a vehicle that he uses as a taxi. He is independent and single. He lives in the Tembladerani region of the city of La Paz. He lives in his parents’ house. The loan is to repair his vehicle and to buy tires. This is the third time that he has asked Impro for a loan. His history qualifies him as client 1, which means good completion of paying his loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cost of repair and maintenance of his taxi and to buy tires

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en: Mrs. Juvy P. is from the town of D'Ban, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old, is married, and is blessed with two school-aged children. Juvy owns and operates a business selling cosmetics and food products in the local community. She earns 5,000 PHP net monthly from her business. In 2009, Juvy joined PMPC to access its programs and services. Currently, she's obtaining her 2nd loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Victor

texts.es:
