Victor es tramitador y realiza todo tipo de tramites judiciales y de saneamiento de documentos 
Vive en la zona de Pasankeri de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa propia.
El crédito será destinado para compra de un equipo dental para su hija ya que ella es Odontologa y quiere equipar su consultorio.
Es tercera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, es un cliente con calificación 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Victor is a “tramitador” (someone who expedites transactions). He works on all types of judicial transactions and on correcting documents. He lives in his own house in the Pasankeri region of the city of La Paz. The loan is to buy dental equipment for his daughter, a dentist. She wants to equip her office. This is the third time that he has asked Impro for a loan. He is qualified as client 1, which means he has good completion of making his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy dental equipment for his daughter, a dentist, to help her equip her dental office

loans.name: Yamina

texts.es:
Yamina tiene un pequeño negocio donde recibe contratos para eventos por servicios de comida, te, y otros 
Vive en la zona de villa tembladerani de la Ciudad de La Paz, en casa de sus padres
El crédito será destinado para compra de vajillas y equipos para cocina  y así con este crédito mejorara sus ingresos y calidad de vida.
Es primera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, las ganas de superarse le dan la oportunidad de obtener este crédito.
texts.en:
Yamina has a small business where she receives contracts to provide food, tea, and other things for events. She lives in her parents’ house in the Villa Tembladerani region of the city of La Paz. The loan is to buy dishes and kitchen equipment to improve her income and quality of life. This is the first time that she has asked Impro for a loan. Her desire to succeed has given her the opportunity to get this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy dishes, pots, and other utensils to improve the service in her catering business

loans.name: Anelyn

texts.en: Anelyn M. is from the village of Labo, Ozamiz City. She is 31 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. Anelyn buy’s coconut shells to process into charcoal and sell in the public market. She has been engaged in this business for six years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In February 2009, Anelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Anelyn is now requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP as additional capital for her existing business and to try expanding the business in volume. She wishes to serve other neighboring towns, too, with her charcoal. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the financial needs of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional coconut shells to make charcoal to sell

loans.name: La Reforma 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Marhta, 23, lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, La Reforma (Reform), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in her group.

Marhta and the other women in La Reforma live in Consuelo, a small town just to the north of San Pedro. Consuelo lacks any kind of reliable electricity and has no potable running water. Marhta has a three-year-old daughter and lives with her mother.

Marhta runs a successful colmado from her home. Colmados are small general stores that sell anything from bread to batteries. Marhta focuses on the sale of food in her colmado, specifically the staples of the Dominican cuisine: rice, beans, flour, oil, and plantains. With her new loan, she will purchase more of these items, along with an expanded selection of beverages.

Marhta hopes to save enough money from her business to buy her family a home. Their current home is on loan from a friend, and Marhta dreams of having a place she can call her own someday. She also hopes to send her daughter to school through to college, so that she can learn as much as possible and have a step up in society. This is Marhta’s third loan with Kiva partner Esperanza, and she has a perfect repayment record so far. Thank you for lending to Marhta and La Reforma group!

loans.use: To purchase rice, beans, flour, oil, plantains and beverages

loans.name: Kingsley

texts.en: Kingsley E. T. is a carpenter who makes and sells chairs, beds, doors and so on, at Elmina market. Kingsley has received junior high education and has been in this business since 2000. He is responsible for paying for his apartment and utility bills. His loan will be used to buy wood, nails, polish, a spraying machine and other equipment to enhance his work. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest into his business.

loans.use: To buy wood, nails, polish, a spraying machine and other equipment

loans.name: Benkola Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkola sont en majorité des femmes veuves ayant en moyenne quarante trois, cinq enfants et vivant dans des familles traditionnelles à Kéléya (relevant de la préfecture de Bougouni) à 100  kilomètres de Bamako (la capitale du Mali).
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et professionnels et  font le commerce d’articles divers. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe avec l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles comptent avoir avec ce prêt, 10 casiers de boissons gazeuses, 70  kilogrammes de légumes frais, 100  kilogrammes d’atiékè et divers articles. Elles s’approvisionnent sur le marché de Kéléya où elles vendent sur des étales (au bord de la route nationale qui relie Bamako à Abidjan) ou en ambulant dans les quartiers du village. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 19.000 FCFA qui servira à payer l’échéance du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The women of group Benkola are mostly widows who average 43 years of age and five children. They live in traditional families in Keleya ( within the Bougouni prefecture) 100 kilometers of Bamako( the capital of Mali). They know each other through their proximity and professional ties and do commerce of various items. They are on their first group loan with Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. They intend to buy 10 crates of carbonated soft drinks,70 kilograms of fresh vegetables, 100 kilograms of 'atieke' and various items with this loan. They get their supplies at the Keleya market where they display for sale ( by the national highway which links Bamako to Abidjan) or by door-to-door in the village neighborhoods. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 19 000FCFA which will be used to repay the loans on time and contribute to the family expenses.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Jiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Jiguiya sont des femmes mariées qui ont  une moyenne d’âge de trente ans et quatre  enfants. Elles vivent dans des foyers polygames traditionnelles à Kéléya située à 100  kilomètres de Bamako (la capitale du Mali) et relevant de la préfecture de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et font essentiellement le commerce d’articles divers. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso et tous les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
Elles s’approvisionnent deux fois par mois au marché de Kéléya où elles vendent sur des  étales et en ambulant.
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter, 25 cartons de savons, 400  litres de miel et 500  kilogrammes de divers condiments alimentaires.
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 32. 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The women in the Jiguiya Group are married and have an average age of 30 and four children. They live in traditional polygamous households in Kéléya located 100 kilometres from Bamako (the capital of Mali) in the Bougouni Prefecture (the third administrative region of the republic of Mali).

They know each other through their neighbourly ties and they sell various items. They are on their fifth group loan with Soro Yiriwaso and all of their previous loans have been repaid correctly.

They stock up twice a month at the Kéléya market where they sell from stalls and as street traders.

With this loan they plan to buy 25 boxes of soap, 400 litres of honey and 500 kilogrammes of various condiments.

They hope to make an average monthly income of 32,000 FCFA that will be used to pay back the loan and contribute to family expenses.

Translated from French by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items for resale

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en: Marilou V. is from Catadman, Ozamiz City. She is 34 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Marilou owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. Captured in the photo is a customer with her. In April 2009, Marilou joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Marilou is now requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce A., a married mother of three children, has a  junior high school background and has been selling second-hand clothes at Elmina as a hawker  since 2000. Her husband interprets at the court.  Joyce uses her income to support him in the payment of school fees and utility bills and will use the loan to purchase a bale of second-hand clothes for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of second-hand clothes for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase storage facilities for her business

loans.name: Mwajabu

texts.en: Mwajabu N. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur. She runs a grocery in Kitunda ward of Dar es Salaam selling both soft drinks and food including wheat flour, maize flour, beans, rice, Coca Cola products and Pepsi Cola.  She is a married woman and has three children: one in primary school, one in secondary school and one in college education. She has been in business for three years. She has constructed a residential house. Her business income is used to pay for school fees, meet the family's daily demands and for business capitalization. She needs a loan of 600,000 Tanzanian shillings to buy more goods.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Froride

texts.en:
Froride N. is 40 years old and is married with seven children aged between 9 and 26. She and her large family live together in Ngoma district, Kibungo province, Rwanda, where she has had a small shop selling various products for the past six years. Her shop is open from 6 in morning to 9 in evening every day.

Froride is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders for the purpose of expanding her business and buying new products and inventory that she believes her customers will want. This should help her to serve her existing clients better and hopefully attract new ones. If so, she will earn more profit. With this extra profit she will have sufficient money to continue to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for her shop

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma  sont des femmes mariées vivant dans des foyers polygames à Dangassa, un village située entre le Mali et la république de Guinée Conakry. Dangassa est à 70  kilomètres de Bamako (la capitale du Mali). Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma ont en moyenne  trente ans,  trois enfants et se sont connues par des liens de famille, de voisinage et d’activités. 
Ce groupe de femmes est spécialisé dans la fabrication et la vente des articles de poteries (canaris, jarre etc.)
Par souci de mieux produire et découler facilement les poteries qu’elles fabriquent, elles ont fait recours au  programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur premier prêt solidaire.
Elles envisagent produire en moyenne 50 canaris de volumes différentes par mois. Elles possèdent la matière première principale qui est de l’argile : sélectionnée, mouillée et pétrie avec la latérite pour donner la forme désirée. Une fois les canaris fabriquées, elles sont  disposées au soleil pour être  séchées puis brûlées par un grand feu, décorées et  rendre lisse les articles.
Une partie de la production est vendue  dans le  marché de Dangassa et la majeure partie est acheminée par pirogue à Bamako pour être vendue.
Elles espèrent  réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  18. 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer l’échéance du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The women in the Sabougnouma group are married and live in polygamous households in Dangassa, a village located between Mali and the republic of Guniea-Conakry. Dangassa is 70 kilometres from Bamako (the capital of Mali). The women of the Sabougnouma group have an average age of 30, three children and know each other through family, neighbourly and business connections.

This group of women specialises in making and selling pottery (jugs, jars etc.).

In order to improve production and sales of the pottery they make, they went to Soro Yiriwaso’s loan programme and are on their first group loan.

They envisage producing an average of 50 jugs of different volumes each month. They have the main raw material, which is clay: selected, moistened and kneaded with laterite to give it the desired shape. Once made, the jugs are left to dry in the sun, then baked in a large fire, decorated and glazed.

A portion of the produce is sold at Dangassa market and the majority is transported by canoe to be sold in Bamako.

They hope to make an average monthly profit of 18,000 FCFA which will be used to pay off the loan and contribute to household expenses.

Translated from French by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To cover labour costs and transport of pottery

loans.name: Jmv

texts.en:
JMV N. is 37 years old and is married with six children aged 3 through 15. He and his family live in Burera district in the Northern Province of Rwanda, approximately three hours drive from the capital city of Kigali.

His village, called Rugarama, is where he has had his business of tending chickens and selling them and their eggs since 2006. His business is open every day from 6 in morning to 5 in evening and he employs two people in his business so that it runs well and gives him some time with his family.

JMV is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to purchase more chickens and eggs that will help him to increase his sales and attract more customers. This should produce additional profits which he will reinvest into his business to create a strong and secure future for his young family.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and eggs

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Augustina M. sells bags of charcoal, rice, sugar and so on at Elmina near the seashore, which she has been doing since 2001. She is married and has four children. Her husband works with electronics. She has been through junior high school. Augustina uses her income to help her husband with the payment of school fees and utility bills. She will use this loan to purchase bags of charcoal and bags of rice to sell. Augustina plans to save the new profits from her expanded business to reinvest in it.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal and bags of rice to sell

loans.name: Kanoumafin Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kanoumafin est composé de six femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 52 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le quartier Bamanan kin de Markala (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des relations de voisinage et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle des femmes du quartier. 
Les membres du groupe Kanoumafin exercent le commerce d’articles divers tels la vente des produits cosmétiques, de pagnes  wax, de céréales, de savons, de parfums,  d’habits  pour enfants etc.
Après avoir bien remboursé les quatre prêts précédents, ce groupe est à son cinquième prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Elles comptent utiliser leur prêt pour acheter, 5 sacs de riz, 3 sacs de niébé, 10 sacs de fonio, 70 pièces de pagnes wax et un rouleau de bazin (à teinter avant d’être vendu). Elles se ravitaillent en céréales à Koutiala, en pagnes wax et bazins au grand marché de Bamako. Les produits sont revendus au comptant et à crédit dans les foires de Dougabougou, Sibila, Siribala, Boussin et Diamarabougou à une clientèle mixte. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 53 000 FCFA  qui sera utilisé dans leurs activités et pour l’achat petit à petit des trousseaux de mariage pour leurs filles. 
Elles ont pour ambition d’entretenir leur collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso afin d’augmenter le plus que possible le volume de leurs activités en épargnant et en contractant le plus de prêts.
texts.en:
The Kanoumafin group is composed of six married women who mainly live in monogamous households, and are on average 52 years old with 4 children. They all live in the Bamanan district of Markala (4th administrative region of Mali), and know each other through neighbourhood relations and their membership in the same traditional women's association in the area. The members of Kanoumafin group run businesses selling various items such as cosmetics, pagnes wax (a type of brightly-printed West African cloth), cereals, soap, perfumes, children's clothing, etc. After having repaid their four previous loans properly, this group is working on their fifth solidarity (group) loan through Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners). The intend to use their loan to buy 5 bags of rice, 3 bags of niebe beans, 10 bags of fonio (a type of grain), 70 pieces of pagnes wax, and a roll of damask (to be dyed before selling). They obtain their supplies of cereals in Koutiala, and their pagnes wax and damask at the grand market in Bamako. The products are sold in cash or on credit at the fairs in Dougabougou, Sibila, Siribala, Boussin, and Diamarabougou to a mixed clientele. They foresee making an average monthly profit of 53,000 FCFA, which will be used for their business and to buy piece by piece their daughters' wedding trousseaus. Their goal is to maintain their collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to increase as much as possible the size of their businesses by saving and obtaining further loans.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of used clothing in bulk for her business

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabougnouman est constitué de 5 femmes, (3 mariées  et 2 veuves)  vivant toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec en moyenne 57 ans et 5 enfants par femme. Elles habitent toutes le quartier Bamanan kin de Markala (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des relations de voisinage et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle des femmes du quartier. 
Ce groupe fait le commerce du divers avec  les fruits (mangue et pastèque), du poisson,  des condiments alimentaires, des céréales du savon etc.
Elles sont à leur 5ème prêt de groupe, après avoir correctement remboursé les précédents. 
Ce nouveau prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 20 paniers de poisson, 10 sacs de mil, 5 sacs d’oignon et 12 cartons contenant 47 morceaux de savon chacun. 
Elles se ravitaillent en poisson au bord du fleuve Niger, en fruits, oignon et savon à la foire hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou. 
Les produits sont revendus  au comptant,  à crédit ou  en ambulant dans les quartiers de Markala et dans les foires de Diamarabougou et Sibila à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 51 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer la scolarité des enfants et compléter chaque jour le prix de condiments.
texts.en:
The Sabougnouman group is composed of 5 women (3 married and 2 widows) averaging 57 years of age and 5 children. They all live in extended traditional families in the Bamanan Kin neighborhood in Markala (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali) and got acquainted thorugh neighbourhood relationships and their membership in the same traditional women's local association.

This group sells various products, such as fruits (mangoes and watermelons), fish, food condiments, cereals, soap, etc. They are seeking their 5th group loan, after having repaid the previous ones without problems. This loan will be used to buy 20 baskets of fish, 10 sacks of millet, 5 sacks of onions, and 12 boxes containing 47 pieces of soap each.

They get their fish supplies from the banks of the Niger River, whereas fruits, onions and soap are purchased at the weekly fair in Diamarabougou. They resell the products for cash, on credit, or as ambulant saleswomen in Markala and in the fairs in Diamarabougou and Sibila, to a clientele comprising mostly women.

They count on turning an average monthly profit of XOF 51'000 (ca US$ 120), to be used to pay the children's scholarship and complete each day the cost of condiments.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 20 baskets of fish, 10 sacs of millet, 5 onion sacks, and 12 boxes containing 47 pieces of soap each

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy Q. is married and has four children. She has received a junior high school education.  Dorothy sells second hand cloths at the Elmina market, which she has been doing since 2001. Her husband is a seaman.  Dorothy uses her income to help her husband support the family in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Dorothy will use the loan to buy bails of second hand clothing for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Dorothy plans to save to reinvest in the  business.

loans.use: Dorothy will use the loan to buy bails of second hand clothing for sale.

loans.name: Demin Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  membres du groupe Demin sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec en moyenne  35 ans, 4 enfants et  vivant  dans des familles monogames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Elles font  généralement la vente  des  poissons fumés et de fruits.    
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter,  35 kg de poissons fumés et 4 chargements de charrette en orange. Elles s’approvisionnent dans les villages avoisinants  KAMALEN SIRAKORO auprès des producteurs.
Elles vendent dans les  différents marchés de Sikasso ville et à domicile, au comptant à clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles ambitionnent emprunter plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  pouvoir aménager un coin pour leur vente.
texts.en:
The four members of the group Demin are essentially married women who average 35 years of age and 4 children each.  They live in monogamous families in KAMALEN SIRAKORO, one of the villages of the Sikasso area (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women are collaborating for the first time with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to meet the needs of their customers.  The group members generally sell fruit and smoked fish.  With their new loan, they intend to buy 35 kg of smoked fish and four cart-loads of oranges.  Supplies are gotten from neighboring villages of KAMALEN SIRAKORO from producers.  Sales are made in cash to customers composed of men and women at the different market places of Sikasso City and in homes. They each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 22,500 francs CFA.  A portion of the profit will be put into savings and used for family needs.  The other portion will be invested in the businesses.  Their ambition is to borrow more capital to satisfy their customers further and to be able to fix up a corner for their sales. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Jiguisèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Jiguisèmè sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans,  5 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles monogames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles font comme activités génératrices de revenus la vente d’ignames, de fruits, de condiments alimentaires et divers  autres articles. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire. Le premier s’est bien dénoué. 
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, une dizaine de paniers d’ignames, 4 chargements de charrette d’oranges et 3 colis  de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent à Kamalen Sirakoro et dans les villages avoisinants et effectuent leurs ventes dans les différents marchés de Sikasso ville et à domicile, au comptant, souvent à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five members of the group Jiguisèmè are essentially married women who average 30 years of age and 5 children each.  They live for the most part in monogamous families in KAMALEN SIRAKORO, one of the villages of the Sikasso area (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women have income-generating work selling yams, fruit, condiments, and various other goods.   They are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to meet the needs of their customers and are now on their second solidarity loan. The first one was settled.  With their new loan, they intend to buy a dozen baskets of yams, 4 cart-loads of oranges, and 3 packets of condiments. Supplies are gotten in Kamalen Sirakoro and in neighboring villages.  Sales are made in cash, often on credit, to customers composed of men and women at the different marketplaces of Sikasso City and in homes.   The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 23,500 francs CFA.  A portion of the profit will be put into savings and used for family needs.  The other portion will be invested in the businesses.  

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe Kotognogontala sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
 Elles font la vente  de condiments alimentaires, de savons,  de chaussures,  de poissons fumés etc.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire. Le précédent s’est bien dénoué
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 3 colis  de condiments alimentaires, 1sac de 100kg de savons traditionnels, 12 douzaines de paires de chaussures en plastique et  35kg de poissons fumés. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elles vendent dans les marchés de KAMALEN SIRAKORO, de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire leurs clientèles et  subvenir aux besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
The five members of the Kotognogontala group are mostly married women averaging 30 years of age and 3 children. Most of them live in monogamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, one of the villages in Sikasso, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They sell food condiments, soaps, shoes, smoked fish, etc.

They work with Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to meet customer demand. They are seeking their second solidarity loan (group loan). The first one went well.

With the new loan, they intend to buy 3 boxes of food condiments, one sack of 100 kg of traditional soaps, 12 dozen pairs of plastic shoes, and 35 kg of smoked fish.

They get their supplies at the market in Sikasso, as well as in the surrounding villages. They sell at the markets in Kamalen Sirakoro, as ambulant saleswomen and at home, for cash and often on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women.

They foresee turning a monthly profit of XOF 23'500 (ca US$ 55) each, to be in part saved and used for the family expenses. The other part will be reinvested in their businesses. They count on increasing their working capital to better meet customer demand, and better provide for their families.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 3 boxes of food condiments, one sack of 100 kg of traditional soaps, 12 dozen pairs of plastic shoes, and 35 kg of smoked fish

loans.name: Saniya Group

texts.fr:
Les  quatre membres du groupe Saniya sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans et 5 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles font  comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente, de chaussures,  de charbon de bois,  de fruits,  des  condiments alimentaires,  de  la friperie etc.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt. Solidaire.  Le prêt précédent a été remboursé correctement.
Avec leur nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 50 sacs de charbon de bois, 3 chargements de charrette  en oranges , 3 colis de condiments alimentaires ,12 douzaines de paires de chaussures en plastique et  2 balles de friperie. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants.
Elles vendent au marché de KAMALEN SIRAKORO, de façon ambulante  et à domicile, au comptant et  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four members of the group Saniya are essentially married women who average 43 years of age and 5 children each.  They live for the most part in polygamous families in KAMALEN SIRAKORO, one of the village in the Sikasso community (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They have revenue-generating work selling shoes, charcoal, fruit, condiments, second-hand clothing, etc.   The group members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the needs of their customers and are now on their second solidarity loan.  The previous loan was properly repaid.  With their new loan, they intend to buy:  3 cart-loads of oranges, 2 packets of condiments, 12 dozen pairs of plastic footwear, and 2 bales of used clothing.  Supplies are gotten at the Sikasso City marketplace and in neighboring villages.  Sales are make in cash and often on credit to customers composed of men and women at the KAMALEN SIRAKORO marketplace, by going door-to-door, and in homes.  The group members each hope to realize an average monthly profit of 23,500 francs CFA.  A portion of the profits will be put into savings and used for the family.  The other portion will be invested in their businesses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her business.

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Madame Salimata Konaté est une femme  de 44 ans et mère de 2 enfants qui vit avec un de ses enfants dans le quartier Torakabougou de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Après des années d’études à l’école moderne sans réussite, elle décida de s’interesser aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment la préparation et la vente de l’encens. Elle a appris cette activité auprès d’une amie à Bamako (capitale du Mali).
Afin d’obtenir un fond de roulement pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter les  matières premières entrant dans la préparation de l’encens.  Sa production est vendue à Bougouni dans sa boutique sise au carrefour de lycée, à Bamako et à Sikasso. Elle est très sollicitée pour la qualité de ses produits et sa clientèle est constituée essentiellement de femmes. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières dans le marché de Bougouni auprès des grossistes.
Elle  espère réaliser  un bénéfice mensuel de 35 000 FCFA qui servira à rembourser les intérêts du prêt et subvenir à ses besoins personnels.
Avec se bénéfice elle envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Ms. Salimata Konaté is a 44-year-old woman and the mother of two children who lives with one of her children in the Torakabougou district of the city of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  After unsuccessful years of modern schooling, she decided to become interested in revenue-generating work, particularly the making and selling of incense.  She learned this business from a friend in Bamako (capital of Mali). To obtain working capital for meeting the needs of her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to buy the raw materials for making incenses.  Her output is sold in Bougouni in her shop near the high school intersection in Bamako and in Sikasso.  She is much sought-after for the quality of her products.  Her customers are made up essentially of women.  She supplies herself with raw materias from wholesalers at the Bougouni marketplace.  She hopes to realize a monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay the loan interest and to meet her personal needs.  With the profits, she envisions expanding her enterprise.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for making incense

loans.name: Salif

texts.fr:
Monsieur Salif Traoré est un homme marié de 35 ans et père de 2 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez lui même dans le  quartier Médine de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, dés à son âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus.
Avant de mener l’activité d’achat et de vente des appareils électroniques, il menait des activités de travaux journaliers.  C’est quelques années plus tard il décida de mener d’autres activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente des appareils électroniques. Il a appris cette activité auprès d’un de ses  amis.  Avec une expérience de 5 ans, Monsieur Salif Traoré maîtrise son activité et est très apprécié à Bougouni.
Pour avoir un fonds de roulement indispensable à l’épanouissement de son entreprise, il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter des appareils électroniques (lampes, torches,radios...). Il est à son premier prêt individuel  avec l’institution. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) et effectue sa vente en détail, au comptant et à crédit. Sa clientèle est composée de la population locale. Il participe régulièrement aux marchés hebdomadaires des villages environnants de Bougouni.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Salif Traoré compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 32 500 FCFA
Dans les années à venir il envisage agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Salif Traoré is a 35-year-old married man with two children. He lives with his wife and children, right in the Médine neighborhood in the town of Bougouni (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having gone to school, Mr. Traoré began his revenue-generating business activities at a young age. He used to work as a day laborer, but some years later he decided to start other income-generating business activities such as the buying and selling electrical appliances. He learned this trade from one of his friends. With five years’ experience, Mr. Traoré has mastered his craft and is highly thought of in Bougouni. To establish a contingency fund, essential for growing his business, he decided to work with Kiva Field Partner, Soro Yiriwaso, to purchase electrical appliances (e.g., lamps, torches, radios). This is his first individual loan with this institution. He stocks up in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali), and sells his wares retail to locals for cash or credit. He regularly participates in the weekly markets in the villages around Bougouni. With this loan, Mr. Traoré expects to make a monthly profit of 32,500 FCFA. In the coming years he hopes to extend his store.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase electrical appliances

loans.name: Blandine

texts.fr:
Madame Blandine Koné est une femme mariée de 28 ans et mère de 2 enfants qui vit avec son mari et ses enfants dans le quartier Torakabougou de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Blandine Koné a abandonné l’école dès son jeune âge pour des raisons sociales. Elle a tenté pendant des années plusieurs activités notamment l’achat et la vente de légumes, mais sans réussite.
C’est ainsi qu’elle décida d’apprendre auprès de son ami, l’achat vente des articles d’alimentation. Après 3 années d’expérience, elle arrive à bien maitriser cette activité, qu’elle exerce dans une boutique  située dans son  quartier de résidence, qui est d’accès facile. 
Ayant fait la connaissance de Soro Yiriwaso à travers une cliente de cette institution, elle décida de collaborer avec dernière avec qui elle est à son premier prêt individuel pour acheter, une grande quantité d’articles pour son alimentation. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako et des fois à Bougouni et effectue sa vente en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
La rotation de son activité est très élévée et elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices elle envisage acheter un congélateur pour la conservation de certains articles.
texts.en:
Mrs. Blandine Koné is a 28 year old married woman, mother of two children. She lives with her husband and her children in the neighborhood of Torakabougou in the town of Bougouni (third administrative region of Mali). Blandine Koné left school at an early age for social reasons. For years she tried several activities, particularly the purchase and sale of vegetables, but without success. Thus, she decided to learn from her friend how to sell various foodstuffs. With three years of experience, she manages her business well. She exercises her activity in a shop located in her neighborhood, which is easily accessible. She learned about Soro Yiriwaso from a customer of this institution. She decided to work with them, and this is her first individual loan that she will use to buy a large quantity of goods for her grocery store. She buys her supplies in Bamako and sometimes in Bougoni. She sells retail for cash or on credit to diverse and varied customers. The turnover in her business is very high and she hopes to make a monthly profit of 50, 000 FCFA. With the profit she plans to buy a freezer for the preservation of some goods.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food items.

loans.name: Walther Isidoro

texts.en:
Walther Isidoro is part of a communal bank consisting of 19 members in Cruz Pata, a town 45 minutes from Cusco.  The group is called Sacro.  He is from Huancayo and lives in Cruz Pata.  He is 48 years old and is married with 5 daughters.

Walther has a bakery where he makes baked goods like cakes and apple pies.  He sells his goods to stores and to tourists. Walther has many regular clients who continue to buy from him. He will use this loan to buy flour and other materials needed by his bakery.

Walther appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy flour and other raw materials needed for his bakery

loans.name: Carla Delfina

texts.es: Carla Delfina es soltera, tiene  2 hijos, el mayor tiene 10 años de edad, la otra hija tiene 2 años de edad, está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 2do crédito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (construcción de los servicios higienicos), vive en la colonia Rubén Darío a 30 kilometros de Nueva Guinea, trabaja como docente de primaria, es una mujer responsable, honesta, de buenas costumbres con con alto espiritu de superación personal y laboral, actualmente esta estudiando una licenciatura en ciencias de la Educación, su  sueño es  tener estabilidad laboral, salud  y una vivienda con mejores condiciones para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Carla Delfina is single and has 2 children. The oldest is a boy and is 10 years old, the other is a 2 year old girl. She is applying for refinancing on her second loan in order to invest in improving her residence (by building bathroom facilities). She lives in the Ruben Dario district, 30 kilometers away from Nueva Guinea. She works as an elementary school teacher. She is an honest and responsible woman with good habits and a high determination for personal and professional advancement. She is currently studying for a degree in Education Science. Her dream is to have professional stability, health and a residence with better living conditions for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Joseph Tobin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building bathroom facilities

loans.name: Hamadi

texts.fr:
Monsieur Hamadi D. est un homme marié de 39 ans et père de 7 enfants. Il réside avec sa femme et ses enfants à Flaba, un village situé à 14 km de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Hamadi abandonna l’école coranique (qu’il fréquentait) à l’âge de 15 ans pour des activités agricoles au profit de ses parents. Quelques années plus tard il commença les activités génératrices de revenus pendant les périodes mortes. Aujourd’hui, ce sont ces activités économiques qui ont pris le pas sur l’agriculture. Depuis maintenant 6 ans, Monsieur Hamadi D. exerce les activités d’achat et de vente de céréales (mil, maïs, fonio, riz etc).  
Cette activité est  menée au village et une partie est vendue dans le marché de Bougouni les jours de foires.
Dans le souci d’agrandir son entreprise, il décida de rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son troisième prêt individuel, après avoir bien remboursé les deux  prêts précédents.
Ce nouveau  prêt servira à acheter des sacs de céréales petit à petit. Il s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants de Bougouni auprès des producteurs et effectue sa vente en détail, en gros et au comptant à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et de consommateurs. 
Monsieur Hamadi D. envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice elle envisage agrandir davantage son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Hamadi D. is a 39-year-old man and the father of seven children. He resides with his wife and children in Flaba, a village located 14 km from the city of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). At age 15, Mr. Hamadi dropped out of Koran school (which he used to attend) for farm work, to his parents’ benefit. A few years later, he started doing revenue-generating work during the slow periods. Today, his commercial work has surpassed farming. For six years now, he has been in business buying and selling grains (millet, corn, fonio, rice, etc.) This business operates in town, and some of the goods are sold at the Bougouni marketplace when the fair takes place. Concerned about expanding his enterprise, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso, with which he is now on his third individual loan after having repaid the two previous ones. This new loan will be used to buy sacks of grain a little at a time. Supplies are gotten from producers from villages surrounding Bougouni. And sales are made in cash at the retail level to customers composed of retailers and consumers. He envisions realizing a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA. With the profits, he envisions expanding his enterprise further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain

loans.name: Tepetlapa Group

texts.es:
La comunidad de San Antonio Tepetlapa se encuentra ubicada en una zona montañosa al norte de Pinotepa Nacional Oaxaca., a 70 KM aproximadamente, los habitantes hablan dialecto mixteco 100%, digenas alli se encuentra formado el grupo solidario TEPETLAPA, integrado por cinco personas la representante es la sra. Josefina T. López,tambien es la traductora del grupo todos originarios del mismo lugar, se dedican a la venta de tamales de carne y de dulce,la sra. Tomasa vende pollo fresco destazado, la sra Josefina ademas de vender tamales en ocaciones se traslada a Pinotepa para adquirir pescado fresco y camaron estos productos se comercializan muy facilmente en el pueblo comenta ya que consideran que es bastante la distancia de tepetlapa a pinotepa y por esa razon muchas personas prefieren comprar el marisco que ella lleva para vender.
estas personas solicitan credito a la fundacion par poder comprar la materia prima para preparar tamales como son:chiles seco, azucar, aceite vegetal, canela en rajas, maíz, manteca, hoja verde de platano, sal, leña, carne fresca de puerco, carne fresca de pollo, y carne de chivo, pollo en pie, pimienta, en el caso de la persona  que vende marisco fresco invierte una cantidad considerable de dinero, ademas de que  paga transporte y flete para llevarlo al pueblo y vender.
nos comentó la cliente Tomasa G. G. y Catalina López López.-que ellas tienen la necesidad de trabajar ya que son viudas y con el dinero que le proporcionan sus hijos no le es sufieciente para cubrir sus gastos y mas cuando tienen que comprar medicamentos que luego tienen precios muy alto, las demas integrantes del grupo trabajan para apoyar a sus esposos en los gastos de sus hijos soveltan gastos escolares que son execivos en muchos de los casos.
Agregó la sra Josefina que todos estan a gusto trabajando con el credito que la institución les otorga ya que tienen considerado continuar solicitand mucho mas financiamiento que le sea posible porque de esa manera podran ayudar cada día mejor a su familia.
texts.en:
The community of San Antonio Tepetlapa is located in a mountainous area 70km north of Pinotepa Nacional in the State of Oaxaca. One hundred percent of the inhabitants speak the Mixtec dialect. Here we find the Tepetlapa Solidarity Group, which consists of five people and is led by Sra. Josefina T. López. She also serves as the translator for the group.

All of the members are originally from San Antonio Tepetlapa and sell beef tamales and sweets. Sra. Tomasa also sells freshly butchered chickens. In addition to selling tamales, Sra. Josefina sometimes travels to Pinotepa to buy fresh fish and shrimp because those products are more readily available there. It is quite a distance between Tepetlapa and Pinotepa, so the locals prefer to buy any seafood that she has available to sell.

Sras. Tomasa G. G. and Catalina López López told us that they need to work because they are widows and the money they set aside for their children is not enough to cover their expenses. It is even more difficult when they have to buy medicines because the prices are too high. The other group members work in order to help their spouses with their children’s expenses, such as their education, which can be excessive in most cases.

Sra. Josefina says they all enjoy working with the loans they receive from Fundación Realidad because it provides them with as much additional financing as possible to help them improve their families each day.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients & supplies for making tamales

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: Madame Khady G. est une sociétaire de la caisse de Baye Laye depuis mai 2009.Elle s’active dans le commerce et la vente de boubou. Elle emprunte 100 000frs et l’objet de prêt est d’acheter des tissus qu’elle va confectionner. Son premier prêt de 50 000 frs lui a permis de réaliser un bénéfice de 100 000 frs et de bien assister S es enfants dans leurs besoins quotidiens. Pour confectionner les habits qu’elle vend elle fait très souvent appel a un tailleur  a qui elle paie la main d’œuvre. Son vœu est d’acheter une machine a coudre et d’embaucher un tailleur pour mieux faire face a la demande croissante surtout comme en ces veilles de fête.
texts.en:
Ms. Khady G. has been a member of the Baye Laye branch since May 2009. She is active in commerce and in selling boubou (long flowing outfits). She is borrowing 100,000 francs, and the purpose of the loan is to buy fabrics for making clothing. Her first loan of 50,000 francs enabled her to realize a profit of 100,000 francs and to help her children with their day-to-day needs. To make the clothing she sells, she often calls upon a tailor and pays for his labor. Her wish is to buy a sewing machine and to hire a tailor for coping better with the growing demand, especially for this period ahead of the holidays.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her capital

loans.name: Hueyapan Group

texts.es:
HUEYAPAN(SAN ANDRéS HUEYAPAN)
      

     La localidad de Hueyapan (San Andrés Hueyapan) está situado en el Municipio de Tétela del Volcán (en el Estado de Morelos). Tiene 6014 habitantes. Hueyapan (San Andrés Hueyapan) está a 2340 metros de altitud, el significado de Hueyapan en náhuatl significa: (Hueyi : mucha  Atlat: Agua, "LUGAR DE MUCHA AGUA"
 
     Bueno en esta ocasión les hablare del grupo Hueyapan que llevan el nombre de su misma localidad, este grupo esta integrado por 5 personas las cuales son:  CELIA M. F., JUSTINA A. S., YOLANDA R. M., YOLANDA A. CORTES Y HERLINDA P. A. con la ultima de las acreditadas que se hace mención es de quien vamos hablar.
  No tiene conocimiento de que o cual es el significado de su nombre,  la edad es de 48 años, curso hasta 6 años de primaria en la escuela que lleva por nombre actualmente "CARLOS A. CARRILLO" de su misma localidad hueyapan.

     La Sra. Herlinda solicito un crédito a Fundacion Realidad, AC. Para poder comprar hilos por mayoreo de distintos colores, comprar también harina de trigo, lo anterior para la elaboración de sus rebozos y gabanes, que es la actividad que la sra. realiza.
Se preguntaran ustedes que tiene que ver la harina con la elaboración de los rebozos.

     Bueno la manera como la sra. prepara el hilo es de la siguiente manera: primero pone a hervir agua y le vierte la harina de trigo, cuando la mezcla adquiere la consistencia de atole, lo retira de lo caliente y lo pone a enfriar, al ya estar frió,  vierte el hilo tipo lana,  lo deja aproximadamente 30 minutos dentro, para que el hilo se ablande y no tenga una consistencia rígida para posteriormente ella poder manipularlo con mas facilidad al momento de estar  hilándolo,  o tejiendo en otras palabras.
 


una vez que lo saca de su mezcla lo exprime y  lo coloca en su tejedor y comienza a tejer el gabán o rebozo, en este proceso de tejido se tarda un día completo para terminarlo una vez terminado lo lava con jabón de pasta neutro y lo pone a secar al sol con esto termina el proceso de la elaboración de un gabán hecho por manos artesanas así sucesivamente los va elaborando cada uno. 


También se dedica al cultivo de flor de temporada por ejemplo,  ahora en este mes de Noviembre sembró flor de  CEMPAZUCHITL por las festividades del día de  MUERTOS y otras F. mas de temporada.

     Ella se integro al grupo de HUEYAPAN en el segundo ciclo,  actualmente es su segundo crédito con el grupo, ella fue invitada  por la Sra. Yolanda R. M.,  la cual es la representante del grupo,  la sra. Yolanda se dedica a la  cosecha de fruta de temporada, tiene huertos de:(MANZANA, PERA, HIGOS, AGUACATE, CAJINICUILES ESTAS SON UNA COMO BAHINAS QUE LLEVAN POR DENTRO UNA ESPECIE DE ALGODINCITOS DULCES, LES PUEDO DECIR QUE SON MUY SABROSOS, TEJOCOTE DE TEMPORADA, la SRA. CELIA M. es mamá soltera: Es la mas relajienta del grupo, ella se dedica a la crianza de borregos y también tiene una pequeña huerta de frutas de temporada, Doña YOLANDA A. es la integrante mas penosa, no quería tomarse la foto con el grupo por que dice que no quieren la vean por Internet sus hijos allá en el norte, la Sra. JUSTINA A., ella cuenta con una pequeña papelería y venta de útiles escolares.

     Bueno regresando con la Sra. Herlinda que es de  quien hablamos, ella tiene su negocio en su propia casa de hecho sus clientes llegan hasta su domicilio para comprarle los rebozos y gabanes, y por su cuenta ella va a las plazas mas cercanas a su comunidad a venderlos,  ya que aun no cuenta con un local establecido donde pudiera exhibir su producto.

 Esta actividad la aprendió a la edad de 10 años, su abuelita materna fue la que le enseño a elaborarlos.

 Sus ingresos son buenos   les gana el 10% o 15% por cada prenda que vende pero no es su único ingreso, aparte de ello también cuenta con una huerta de árboles frutales, crianza y venta de borregos. Ella es una persona muy trabajadora y entusiasta.
 
    Ella realiza su actividad en su propia casa en SAN ANDRES (HUEYAPAN), le es de mucha importancia seguir dedicándose a esta actividad por que sabe que son  muy pocos artesanos la que la realizan aquí en el estado de Morelos aunado a que es herencia de su abuelita.

  La parte que mas le gusta de este trabajo es porque sabe que son indispensables estas prendas en su comunidad debido a que casi todo el año hace mucho frió y que de ello ha sacado adelante a sus hijos más pequeños.

     Ella en su actividad y en su comunidad no tiene competencia, aunque sí ha enfrentado algunos desafíos; como los costosos precios de la materia prima y el tener que viajar constantemente a la ciudad de Cuautla para adquirirlos.

  Doña Herlinda,  conforme va recibiendo sus créditos lo va invirtiendo de inmediato, ella en este ciclo solicito la cantidad de $ 5,000.00 pesos, para la compra del material y como ella trabaja sola no se da abasto para  elaborar mas producto,  pues se ve apurada y necesita contratar a mas gente para producir más de lo que ella hace y quiere a darse a conocer con algún buen comprador de mayoreo y hacer crecer su negocio.


La Sra. Herlinda es viuda desde hace un año, tiene 6 hijos, el hijo mayor se llama Lorenzo, el se fue a estados unidos desde hace 4 años, el segundo se llama Genaro el es empleado de un restaurante, el tercero se llama Alejandro el vive con doña herlinda y le ayuda en casa y se dedica al campo, su única hija se llama Judith es una señorita de 18 años y ella trabaja como empleada en la ciudad de Cuernavaca y por ultimo los 2 pequeñitos que son: Julio que va en segundo de Secundaria y Alberto en 4º. De Primaria ellos conforman su familia actualmente.

Ella hace mención sobre su parte del pueblo, me dice que es un clima muy frió pero la tierra en la que cultivan es muy generosa con ellos, por que todo el año sus árboles frutales le dan mucha producción. Su casa esta construida con block de adobe de una sola planta con 3 cuartos y techo de lámina de asbesto. De antemano su negocio le a ayudado mucho desde que su esposo falleció por que de ello se a mantenido y a salido adelante.

Sus planes de esperanza que ella tiene es que en un futuro pueda exportar sus prendas y tener un buen comprador para darse a conocer su artesanía.

Ella esta feliz y contenta por la oportunidad que le dieron de ser parte de Fundacion Realidad, A.C. como acreditada.

    “Agradecimiento por el préstamo que adquirió y por confiar en ella y agradecerles  por existir Fundacion Realidad,  gracias por  ayudar  y comprender la situación de cada uno de los integrantes y de cada localidad a la que visitan y forman grupos para apoyarlo para mejorar su calidad de vida y la de nuestras familias,  muchas,  muchas gracias por ser una micro financiera de apoyo y ayuda.”
texts.en:
The community of San Andrés Hueyapan (or Hueyapan, for short) is situated in the town of Tétela del Volcán in the State of Morelos. It has 6014 inhabitants. Hueyapan is 2340 meters above sea level. In the Nahuatl language, Hueyapan means “place of abundant water” (Hueyi = “many”; Atlat = “water”).

The Hueyapan Group bears the same name as this location. It is composed of 5 members: Celia M. F., Justina A. Sardiñas, Yolanda R. M., Yolanda A. Cortex, and Herlinda P. A.. We will focus on Herlinda’s story.

Not knowing what her name means, Herlinda is 48 years old. She completed her education through the 6th grade at the Carlos A. Carillo School in Hueyapan. Sra. Herlinda requested a loan from Fundación Realidad in order to buy yarn in different colors at wholesale. In addition, she will purchase wheat flour to use in making shawls. You’re probably wondering what flour has to do with producing shawls. Herlinda prepares the yarn in the following manner:

First, she combines flour and boiled water. When the mixture becomes the consistency of porridge, she allows it to cool before adding the woolen yarn. She lets the yarn soak in the flour mixture for 30 minutes or until it no longer has a rigid consistency. This process makes the yarn easier to manipulate for weaving. After the yarn is finished soaking, any excess mixture is squeezed out before the yarn is washed with neutral soap and set out to dry in the sun. The entire process takes a full day and prepares the yarn for use in handicrafts.

In addition, Herlinda also grows seasonal flowers. For example, in the month of November, the cempazuchitl (a miniature yellow marigold, an Aztec symbol of death) is planted for the “Día de los Muertos” celebrations.

Herlinda recently joined the Hueyapan Group, which is now in its second loan cycle. She was invited by Yolanda R. M., the group leader. Sra. Yolanda has several orchards where she grows seasonal fruits such as apples, pears, figs, avocados, cajinicuiles (a tropical fruit with flesh that looks like cotton candy), and tejocote. Sra. Celia M. is a single mother and the most relaxed member of the group. She raises sheep and also has a small fruit orchard. Doña Yolanda Argon is the most guarded member. She did not want her photograph taken so that her children would not see her on the Internet. Sra. Justina A. manages a small stationery shop where she sells school supplies.

Getting back to Herlinda’s story, she operates a home business in Hueyapan where her customers visit her to purchase shawls and overcoats. She says she also travels to other venues closest to her community to sell her products since she does not have an established vending location. Herlinda started weaving when she was 10 years old and learned this skill from her maternal grandmother.

Herlinda makes a profit of 10 to 15 percent from each garment that she sells. Apart from her agricultural activities, this is her only source of income. She is a hardworking and enthusiastic person. This business is very important to her because it represents an extension of her grandmother’s heritage. She faces very little competition since there are few craftspeople who work in the State of Morelos. However, Herlinda still faces some challenges. The cost of materials is high and she must travel constantly to the city of Cuautla to acquire them. She is proud of the fact that her garments are indispensable in her community because of the cold that exists for most of the year. Another benefit of the business is that it has enabled her younger children to get ahead.

Doña Herlinda will immediately apply her loan of 5000 MXN toward the purchase of materials. Since she works alone, she cannot generate more items on her own. She feels rushed and needs to hire more people to produce more garments. Herlinda hopes to come into contact with a good wholesale buyer so that she can grow her business.

She became a widow last year. Herlinda’s six children are as follows: - Lorenzo is her eldest son and left for the United States four years ago. - Her second child Genaro is employed at a restaurant. - Her third child Alejandro lives with her and helps around the house and on the farm. - Her only daughter is named Judith. She is 18 years old and works as a clerk in the city of Cuernevaca. - Julio attends high school. - Alberto is in fourth grade.

In her part of town, the climate is very cold but the land is fertile and enables their fruit trees to be productive. Her single floor house is made of adobe blocks. It has three rooms and an asbestos sheet roof. Now that her husband has passed away, her business enables her to maintain her lifestyle and move forward. In the future, she hopes to export her garments and become connected with a good buyer that specializes in handicrafts.

Herlinda says she is satisfied and happy to be given the opportunity to be part of Fundación Realidad. She says, “We are grateful that Fundación Realidad exists and for the loan that was provided to us. They take the time to understand the situation of each member and the communities in which they live. By forming support groups, we are able to help each other improve the quality of life for our families. We are very, very thankful that Fundación Realidad is a microfinance institute that provides both support services and financial assistance.”

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase yarn in different colors & kilos of flour

loans.name: Cesar Augusto

texts.es: Cesar Augusto de 36 años de edad es casado, tiene 2 niños, de 14 y 4 años respectivamente, labora para la Alcaldia de Juigalpa como colector de ingresos desde hace 11 años.  Esta solicitando su 2do credito y espera seguir siendo beneficiado con el Fondo Kiva, pues desea seguir mejorando su casa de habitacion construyendo un pequeño porche, levantar un muro y hacer las gradas, poco a poco a ido haciendo su casita mas comoda para sus hijos, su esposa se encarga del cuido de la casa y de los niños. El mayor sueño de Cesar es lograr tener su casa con las condiciones basicas para que sus hijos crezcan en ambiente comodo, ademas que estos estudien y sean personas de bien.
texts.en:
Cesar Augusto is 36 years old, married, and has 2 children, ages 14 and 4 respectively. He has been working for the town of Juigalpa as a tax collector for 11 years. Cesar is requesting his 2nd loan and hopes to continue as a Kiva beneficiary. He wants to continue his home improvements by building a small porch, erect a wall, and install steps. Gradually he has been making his home more comfortable for his children. His wife is in charge of looking after the children and maintaining the home.

Cesar dreams of having a home with the basic necessities so that his children can grow up in a comfortable environment. He also wants them to continue their studies and become good people.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a small porch, erect a wall, and install steps

loans.name: Kairo Jose

texts.es: Kairo Jose de 47 años de edad es casado, tiene 3 niños, el mayor de 10 años, otro de 4 años y bebesito de meses, labora para el MINSA como tecnico radiologo desde hace 8 años.  Su esposa se encarga del cuido de la casa y de los niños ademas vende producots Zermat y Avon para obtener ingresos adicionales que ayuden con los gastos de la familia. Kairo esta solicitando su 3er credito y espera ser beneficiado con el Fondo Kiva, para mejorar su casa de habitacion construyendo un pequeño porche, para que sus hijos tengan un lugarcito para jugar, sueña con ir dandole poco a poco las condiciones necesarias a su casa para sus pequeños crezcan en un ambiente agradable, ademas desea que estudien y sean personas de bien que saquen adelante al pais.
texts.en:
47 year old Kairo Jose is married and has three kids. The eldest child is 10, the middle child is 4, and there is a small baby only a few months old. For the past eight years he has worked for the Ministry of Health as a radiology technician. His wife looks after the house and children and also sells Zermat and Avon products to earn extra income to help with the family expenses. Kairo is requesting his third loan and hopes that the KIVA fund will enable him to improve his house by building a small porch so that his kids will have a place where they can play. He dreams of giving his kids, little by little, the necessary things in their house for them to grow up in a pleasant home environment. He also wants them to study and to become good people who will move their country forward.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Hynd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a porch for his family's house

loans.name: Gloria Alejandra

texts.es:
La señora Gloria Alejandra D. L. es madre soltera y tiene bajo su responsabilidad a tres hijos que ya son adolescentes. 
Solicita el préstamo para poder comprar un equipo D. cómputo, para que sus hijos puedan hacer la tarea, sin salir D. la casa ya que tiene miedo que les pueda pasar algo y si ella pueD. estar al pendiente D. ellos. 
Doña Gloria Alejandra trabaja cuidando una persona ya mayor D. edad, por las mañana y así esta al pendiente D. sus niños. Este es el ingreso que tiene, para darles lo mejor a sus hijos y con el cual planea pagar el crédito.  Ya a tenido un préstamo con FVP al cual lo pago puntual mente, es por eso que nueva mente nos esta solicitando este crédito para que sus hijos tengan una buena herramienta estudiar y salir adelante en la vida.
texts.en:
Gloria Alejandra is a single mother and is responsible for three children who are now teenagers. She is requesting this loan to buy computer equipment so that her kids can do their homework without having to leave the house because she is afraid that something might happen to them and she wants to be able to keep an eye on them.

Gloria Alejandra works caring for an elderly lady in the morning, and looks out for her children this way. She uses this income to give the best to her children and she will use it to pay back the loan. She has already had one loan from FVP which she paid back punctually. She is requesting a new loan from us so that her children will have a good tool for studying and can advance in life.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Hynd, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a computer for her children

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.es:
A la vivienda de la señora Alejandra O. le está haciendo falta los acabados del interior, pero en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder realizar la mejora. 
Es por eso que está solicitando un préstamo y así poder comprar el material y pagarle a la persona que realizara la mejora. 
La señora Alejandra es empleada de una fabrica en el departamento de jefa de producción, este ingresos es para su familia ya que es madre soltera y tiene un hijo bajo su responsabilidad.  También planea pagar el crédito con una parte de su sueldo.
texts.en:
The interior of Señora Alejandra O.’s home is not finished, but, at this time, she does not have the money to be able to improve it. It is for this reason that she is requesting a loan so that she will be able to buy materials and to pay someone to make the improvements. Señora Alejandra is a factory employee in the chief production department. Her income goes to her family since she is a single mother and is responsible for her son. She also plans to repay her loan with a part of her salary.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Finishing the interior of her home

loans.name: Mosoc Runa Group

texts.es:
Nuestros socios, pertenecen al banco comunal “MOSOC RUNA”, este nombre es D. origen quechua y traducido al español. "MOSOC" significa nuevo y "RUNA" significa hombre (en el sentido D. la raza humana), nosotros lo traducimos como Gente Nueva. Nuestros miembros son 15 socios, todos ellos son muy amigables y emprendedores. Los socios viven en la ciudad del Cusco, la mayoría D. ellos son comerciantes independientes y tienen actividades similares.   

Nuestros socios alternan sus diversas actividades con el comercio minorista en la ciudad Cusco. Ellos tienen diferentes negocios como venta D. ropa, productos D. belleza y otras cosas. Una D. las socias su actividad es procesar tejido con lana D. alpaca y después confeccionar chompas, chulos, chalinas, guantes y vestidos. Ella exporta sus productos al país D. Japón. Otra socia tiene una tienda escolar donD. venD. golosinas, galletas, pasteles, etc. 

Todos los miembros del banco comunal son nuevos socios y están deseosos D. invertir el préstamo en sus nuevos negocios y D. este modo hacerlos crecer, esto ayudará a mejorar la calidad D. vida D. sus hogares y les dará mayor producción y mayor ganancia.

Los socios valoran y agradecen el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y así mismo se comprometen a cumplir con el pago D. sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.

(El socio RUBEN no esta en la foto por que estaba trabajando como profesor)
texts.en:
Our members belong to the communal bank " MOSOC RUNA." This name is of Quechua origin and translated to Spanish. "MOSOC" means new and "RUNA" means man (in a human racial sense), we translate it as New People. There are 15 members, who are all friendly and enterprising. The members live in the city of Cusco. The majority of them are independent entreprenuers and have similar jobs. The members alternate their diverse activities with minority commercialism in Cusco. They have different businesses such as selling clothes, beauty products and other enterprises as well. One of the member's jobs is to process alpaca wool into fabric and later make sweaters, winter hats, scarves, gloves, and dresses. She exports her products to Japan. Another member has a store in a school where she sells sweets, cookies, cakes, etc. All of the members of the communal bank are new and wish to invest the loan in new businesses. This way they plan to make their businesses grow, improve their standards of living, and increase production and profits The members value and are thankful for the offered loan through this resource and in the same manner commit to repay their loans in the established time period. (Member RUBEN is not in the photo because he was working as a teacher.)

Translated from Spanish by Susan Garza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell clothes, food, cosmetics, and the production of sweaters.

loans.name: Martha Belgica

texts.en:
Martha Belgica S. V. is 25 years old and lives in the Fortin district of Guayaquil. Fortin is a semi-urban, marginalized zone without paved roads, water pipes, or a sewer system. Ms. S. lives in a fragile wood and cane home situated on a steep incline.  In order to support herself and her son, Ms. S. sells Yanbal products.  Yanbal is a popular Latin American cosmetics company, which allows women to be direct sellers of their beauty products.  Originally, Ms. S. was paid a "finder's fee" by a friend who sold Yanbal products, but about 1 year ago she decided to become a full-time sales person.  Ms. S. has built a base of approximately 20 fixed clients throughout Guayaquil, and she travels to their homes with perfumes and colognes. 

Ms. S. is requesting a loan to purchase more Yanbal products.  She needs the loan because she offers her clients a “lay away” plan and it often takes them  a couple of months to pay the full price of the products (its costs $26 for perfume and $40 for cologne).  In the future, Ms. S. wishes to secure her cane home with cement. Hopefully, an increase in sales will help her achieve this.  She is grateful for any support we can provide her business, so that her family may prosper!

loans.use: To buy perfume and cologne to sell

loans.name: Henrrita Ii Group

texts.es:
El grupo Henrrita II es nuevo miembro de Adim y esperan con este primer préstamo seguir progresando. Las integrantes son Egna María L. Valdivido a  de 32 años quien vende ropa al comienzo ella compra pequeños encargos pero cuando fue creciendo empezó a comprar según colocaba. 

Las otras integrantes son Erika P., ella vende frijoles cocidos, helados, chocobananos y hielo y Alicia M. vende gaseosa, caramelos y chiverías.
texts.en:
The Henrrita II group is a new member of Adim. They hope that with this new loan they will keep progressing. One member is Egna María L. Valdivido, 32. She sells clothes. In the beginning she bought small orders. But, as the business was growing, she started to buy according to what she could sell. Erika P. is another member. She sells cooked beans, ice cream, chocolate bananas, and ice. The other member is Alicia M.. She sells soft drinks, candy, and yogurt.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing merchandise

loans.name: G.s. La Paz  Ii Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario compuesto por dos personas, tiene 12 créditos y es uno de los grupos que han sido responsables con su cuota. La señora Dominga vende ropa la cual ella elabora ya que es costurera. Desde hace 25 años que se dedica a este negocio, tiene 52 años de edad y junto a su esposo se han esforzado para sacar adelante a la familia ya que es una de sus prioridades es que su hija logre salir adelante, solicita un financiamiento para la compra de materia prima del negocio, ella vende su producto en Managua y la paz centro y cuenta con todos los servicio básicos.

La señora Virginia posee un negocio que es la sastrería,  vende su producto en el mercado oriental y en la paz centro desde hace 35 años,  es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos los cuales se encuentran estudiando ya que con su esfuerzo a logrado sacarlos adelante, solicita un financiamiento para invertirlo en la compra de materia prima del negocio. el sueño de estas 2 mujeres es que sus familias cuenten con los ingresos necesarios.
texts.en:
This unified group is comprised of two people. They have 12 loans, and they are one of the groups that has been responsible with their payment. Dominga is a seamstress, and she sells clothes that she makes. She has been in this business for 25 years. She is 52. Together with her husband they have put forth great effort to get their family ahead. One of their priorities is to have their daughter be successful. She is asking for a loan to buy raw material for her business. She sells her products in Managua and La Paz. She has all of the basic services. Virginia has a tailoring business. For 35 years she has been selling her products in the Oriental Market and in the La Paz center. She is a single mother, and she has two children who go to school. Through her efforts she has gotten them ahead. She is asking for a loan to buy raw material for her business. The dream of these two women is that their families have the needed income.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Doña Nubia Group

texts.es:
Alba Nubia Mejía E. es la fundadora del grupo Nubia de 59 años ella hace un poco de todo ella vende frijoles cocidos, pinolillo, cría y vende gallina, pinol y limones. Ella hace quince  años comenzó poniendo a cocer tres libras de frijoles y después fue creciendo.

Las otras integrantes del grupo son Agustina Ángelo F. Obando ella comenzó vendiendo tortilla y luego introdujo productos lácteos y chicharron. Natalia A. tiene una pequeña venta.
texts.en:
Alba Nubia Mejía E. is the founder of the group. Nubia is 59. She does a little bit of everything. She sells cooked beans and “pinolillo” (a drink with cornstarch and water). She raises and sells chickens. She sells “pinol” (a corn/cocoa-based powder used to make drinks) and lemons. Fifteen years ago she started cooking three pounds of beans. After that it started growing. Agustina Ángelo F. Obando is another member of the group. She started selling tortillas. Then she introduced dairy products and “chicharron” (fried pork rind). The other member, Natalia A., has a small sales business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beans, corn, and cocoa

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is part of a communal bank consisting of 19 members in Cruz Pata, a town 45 minutes from Cusco.  The group is called Sacro.  She  is from Cruz Pata and lives there as well.  She is 41 years old and is married with 3 children.

She owns her own land where she farms various types of cereals, grains and potatoes.  She will use this loan to buy fertilizer for her fields.

Martha appreciates and thanks you for the loan and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her fields

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es: La Señora Maria Elena tiene la edad de 30 años. La actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 5 años que posee este negocio. La ubicación de su negocio es de manera ambulante ya que es la única manera de mostrar su mercadería. Por lo que sus inicios surgen con muy poco capital,  y con fondos propios pero con muchas ganas de salir adelante. Por lo que tenía que pagar las cuentas de su vivienda y además buscar el alimento diario.
