Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.Tên C. thức của nhóm vay này là 11.1.1 Nam Ngạn (02.11.1.1).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập C. của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm sấy khô trong cộng đồng địa phương. H. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 8 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 1.200.000 VND. Vào 2009, H. đã tham gia Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài C. giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. H. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1.626.900 VND từ Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1. Lại Thị H. (2) là 40 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích C. của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng thịt.

2. Nguyễn Thị C. (3) là 32 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích C. của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.

3. Hoàng Thị C. (4) là 51 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích C. của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.

4. Hoàng Thị L. (5) là 43 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích C. của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

5. Ngô Thị L. (6) là 60 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích C. của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán hàng gia dụng.

Về Thanh H. Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài C. bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & C. xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell	.

loans.name: Mrs. Chamroeun Born Village Bank Group

texts.en: The village bank loan consists of nineteen people who all live in Trapeang Veaeng village in Takeo province. Mrs. Chamroeun B. is the village bank president, selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectar field of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation she is a weaver. Now she is requesting a loan to buy more raw materials for her weaving. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's life with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Tun Heng Ly, is a teacher in a high school in the local district. Mrs. Chamroeun B. is 55 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is a beautician, another is employed in an organization, and the remaining attends the local school. All the members are presented in the picture bU. some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials for her weaving.

loans.name: Emanuel

texts.en: Emanuel O. is a Tanzanian business man.  He runs a business where he sells home products at the Kariakoo city shopping center. He purchases goods from wholesale and retail shops and resells to customers. He has been in the business for four years. He is not yet married. The business income is used to provide capital for the business and meet his daily needs. He is requesting a loan of TSZ 600,000 to buy more goods.

loans.use: To buy more products.

loans.name: Laura Manuel

texts.pt:
Laura Manuel N. nasceu no distrito da Namaacha, na fronteira com a Suazilândia, província de Maputo, tem 27 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 01 filho com 05 anos de idade. Fez o nível superior, vive com a família numa casa cedida pela tia. Para alem da família, não sustenta mais ninguém.

Saiu de Namaacha para Boane, Província de Maputo com os seus pais ainda muito nova. Depois  da formação na Universidade Pedagógica há 4 anos, começa a trabalhar como Docente numa das escolas no Distrito Boane. Faz um horário único das 7h as 13:30h, e tem um salário mensal de 6.074.49mt. poupa algum por mês, com as sua colegas através de sistema tradicional de poupança (Xitique).

Já teve um empréstimo no Banco comercial BIM, no valor de 25.000.00mt, que foi aplicado para a compra de material de construção. Conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma irmã que também é cliente desta instituição e este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (chapas de zinco, aros de portas, cimento e outros) para dar continuidade com a sua obra.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo, para poder aceder a mais créditos no futuro, para concluir a sua casa e passar a viver na residência própria.
texts.en:
Laura Manuel N. was born in Namaacha, in the border with Suazilandia, Maputo province. She is 27 years old, married and the mother of a 5 year old boy. She went to college to become a teacher, and lives with her family in a house given to her by her aunt. Besides her family, she doesn't support anyone else. She works as a teacher at a school in Boane District, from 7AM to 1PM every day, and makes U$210 per month. She is asking for a U$525 loan in order to buy construction supplies (zinc plates, cement and others) to finish building her house. She expects to pay it back in no time.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction Supplies

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en: Beatriz is busy managing her store. She is 57 years-old and still has a strong determination in life. Beatriz is happily married to Fernando O.. Her husband cultivates their rice fields and also raises ducks in the village they reside in. The couple are blessed with six children and all of them already have their own families. She is thankful because her children are still helping her in her business. Beatriz wants to expand her store but lacks the capital to do so.  Therefore, she would like to ask for additional capital from KIVA lenders in order to expand and improve her business.  She is asking for Php 5, 000.00. This amount will be a big help towards sustaining their basic needs and for their future welfare. She hopes that she will obtain this amount.

loans.use: Additional capital for store expansion and improvement.

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
H. Nguyễn Thị (20201070032) is a 30 year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  H. is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Trung Bạn nhóm 05 (5).


H. is married and has 2 school-age children.  To make a living, H. owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling herbs & spices in the local community.  H. has been engaged in this business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3.600.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007, H. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities.  H. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.256.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6.048.000 VND which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the 4th loan she has taken out from SEDA.  H. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Nguyễn Thị M. (20201070033) is a 36 year-old female who is requesting a 4.704.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making & selling food.


2.  Nguyễn Thị L. (20201070034) is a 36 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making & selling food.


3.  Nguyễn Thị T. (20201070035) is a 56 year-old female who is requesting a 4.704.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


4.  Nguyễn Thị C. (20201070036) is a 43 year-old female who is requesting a 4.256.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


H. Nguyễn Thị (20201070032) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  H. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Trung Bạn nhóm 05 (5).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các loại thảo mộc & gia vị trong cộng đồng địa phương.  H. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 8 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, H. kiếm được khoảng 3.600.000 VND.  Vào 2007, H. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  H. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.256.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.048.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn Thị M. (20201070033) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.704.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


2.  Nguyễn Thị L. (20201070034) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


3.  Nguyễn Thị T. (20201070035) là 56 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.704.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Nguyễn Thị C. (20201070036) là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.256.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
“Poverty is not a hindrance to success!” is an inspiring quotation from Mrs. Erlinda P. the responsible housewife of Mauro P.. They happily live in the village located at Barangay Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya, with their five children. Despite the economic crisis, they aim to support the schooling of their children so that they will find a stable job someday. As a fruit of their patience and sacrifices, two of their children graduated from college while the others are still studying.

For the sake of their future, Erlinda and her husband till their land twice a year and plant palay (rice) and some vegetables. To earn additional income Erlinda ventured in the buying and selling of dry goods like blankets, towels and floor mats. She sells them in their village through retailing.

Recognizing that the dry-goods business is really profitable, she now wants to acquire more dry goods but she has only a little capital. Thus, she wants to borrow additional capital of Php 10,000 from Kiva lenders to be used in acquiring the said products. She believes that the lenders will grant her requested loan.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her dry goods business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 42 year old married woman with six children, who are between six and twenty-three years old. All of her children go to school. Betty resides and rents a two room house, in which she is staying with four people. Thankfully, her family has access to electricity and running water. Betty also takes care of additional family members. Her family gets three meals a day.

Betty owns a stall in Kawempe where she sells second hand clothes. She also goes to mobile markets; in total, she works seven days a week. On average, Betty receives 10 customers a day. This will be Betty's fifteenth loan. Her monthly expenses include rent for her business premises and residence, school fees for her children and feeding the family. Betty wants to use this loan to buy more second hand clothing. She wants to expand her business and eventually sell wholesale only.

loans.use: purchasing more second hand clothes

loans.name: Rommel

texts.en:
Rommel A. is from the village of Gango Ozamiz. He is 39 years old and single. To make a living, Rommel runs a motorcycle transport business. He has been engaged in this business for over 1 year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rommel joined GDMPC in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Rommel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rommel is currently requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and accessories. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rommel from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership consists of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing tires and accessories

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
According to her neighbors, Felisa is an industrious mother. Every day, she sells some food, like snacks. Her daily net income is PHP 300. She wants to borrow PHP 5,000 in order to have additional working capital for her business. Although she is currently content with her life, she is facing some health problems; for instance, she was diagnosed with cholecystitis (gallstones). Still, she struggles very hard to support her family.

Felisa is grateful to the people who support her, especially her children. She is married to Gualberto, a painter, and they are blessed with four hardworking children. In total, six family members live together at the village of Cabaruan, Cauayan City, in the province of Isabela. Felisa hopes that Kiva will loan her the amount she has requested so that she can purchase some more grocery items to sell.

loans.use: purchasing more grocery items to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Mot Chum Village Bank Group

texts.en: Thirteen people all living in Angk village in Kandal province make up the village bank loan. Mrs. Mot C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members, and they all will use the loan for different purposes. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land used to cultivate rice to earn a living. On this plantation she has an obstacle in that she does not have enough money to cultivate rice, and thus she decided to ask for a loan. Her husband, Mr. Tith Sary, is a laborer who has been hired by a villager to work on his farm. Mrs. Mot C. is 41 years old and the mother of five children who are all enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy rice seeds for rice cultivation

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora C. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia City. She is 57 years old and is married; she has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Leonora owns and runs a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling firewood to the local community. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Leonora joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Leonora is currently requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Leonora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: investing in expanding the business

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en: Anjelina J. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur. She is a married woman with four children, one of whom is in primary school, and three of whom are in secondary school. Anjelina runs a food store in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her goods directly from either wholesale shops or the producers. With the income her business has generated, she has been able to build two houses and pay for her children's school fees. She has been a borrowerer with YOSEFO for the last 10 years; currently, she is requesting a loan of TSHS 800,000, with which she will buy more business goods.

loans.use: expanding her business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 41 year married woman with seven children, all of whom are between 10 and 23 years old. All of her children go to school. Betty rents and resides in a one room house; she stays there with four other people. They have access to electricity, but no running water. Betty also takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals a day.

Betty owns a stall in Kawala, where she sells smoked fish, eggplants, sugar cane, tomatoes, oranges and onions. She also goes to mobile markets; in total, she works seven days a week. On average, she receives 30 customers a day. Betty been in this business for six years and with MCDT six years as well. She is servicing her twelfth loan with the same groupmates. Her monthly expenses include rent for her business premises and residence, school fees for her children and supporting the family. Betty wants to use this latest loan to buy more sacks of eggplants, fish, tomatoes and onions. She wants to expand her business and eventually sell wholesale alone.

loans.use: purchasing more sacks of eggplants, fish, tomatoes and onions

loans.name: Mrs. Sarim Kong Village Bank Group

texts.en: The village bank loan consists of sixteen people who all live in Damnak Trayueng village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sarim K. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Tuon Kha, is a farmer who owns a piece of land he uses to cultivate rice. Since Mrs. Sarim K.’s pig breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets for breeding, and would use the rest of loan to buy fertilizers to support the rice field. Mrs. Sarim K. is 37 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding and to buy fertilizers to support the rice field

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane C. is from the village of  Batangan, Valencia City. She is 37 years old and married with 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns and runs a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling scrap metal and other used products like plastics, iron and empty bottles to the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Mary Jane joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane is currently requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Mary Jane from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: investing in expanding the business

loans.name: Eleanor

texts.en:
Eleanor is 34 years old and married; her husband manages their 2.5 hectare rice field. They are blessed with four children: Elton, 16 years old and a high school student, BabyJhon, 12 years old and in sixth grade, Janella, 11 years old and in fifth grade, and Rea Faye, who is only 2 years old. Eleanor is a responsible mother; in addition, she helps support her parents through her direct selling of Avon products. She is striving hard to succeed in this business so that she can improve her family's standard of living. 

Eleanor would like to borrow PHP 8,000 from the Kiva lenders. She will use this amount to purchase more Avon cosmetics, apparel and other products that she can then offer to her customers. She believes increasing her capital will allow her to increase her income.

loans.use: additional capital for her personal products business

loans.name: Mrs. Vanna Huy Village Bank Group

texts.en: A village bank loan consists of twenty seven people who are located in BoE. village in Kandal province. All the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Vanna H. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land used to cultivate rice to earn a living. On this plantation she faces an obstacle because her field has infertile soil which badly affects her crops. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Vanna H. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the rice field. She is 35 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is a driver while the others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the rice field

loans.name: Gilda Arlindo

texts.pt:
Gilda Arlindo B., nasceu em Mangunze, distrito de Manjacaze, província de Gaza, tem 38 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 02 filhos com 18 e 13 anos de idade, a ultima vai a escola. Fez a 7ªclasse, parou de estudar por falta de condições financeiras por parte dos pais. Vive na casa própria na cidade de Maputo e para alem dos filhos sustenta também um neto que vive com ela.

Em 1998 saiu de Manjacaze para Maputo com seu marido a procura de emprego, primeiramente viviam numa casa arrendada e pouco tempo depois construíram a própria residência onde vivem ate hoje. É comerciante há 03 anos faz 12 horas diárias e não tem empregado. Aprendeu o negócio com o pai ainda jovem, que também faz a mesma actividade. Vende mais os produtos de 1ª necessidade e tem um rendimento de 500.00mt por dia, consegue poupar 50.00mt diários através de sistema tradicional de poupança (Xitique).

Nunca teve empréstimos com outras instituições de crédito, conheceu a Hluvuku através da sua Vizinha. Este é o 1º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar mais produtos (arroz, farinha, óleo de cozinha e outros) para satisfazer ainda mais a sua clientela.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a mais empréstimos no futuro e evoluir ainda mais o seu negócio.
texts.en:
Gilda Arlindo B. was born in Mangunze, Majacaze District, Mozambique. She is 38 years old, married and the mother of two children ages 18 and 13, the younger one goes to school. She finished 7th grade but had to drop it because of her parent's financial difficulties. She lives at her own house and besides her children she also supports a grandson that lives with them. In 1998 she left Manjacaze with her husband to look for work in Maputo. They lived at a rented house at first, and later on they built their own house where they live to this day. She's been a saleswoman for the past 3 years, works 12 hours days and has no employees. She learned the business with her father who also did that for a living. She sells first necessity products and makes around 500.00MT per day. She's able to save 50.00MT per day. She's never had loans with other institutions and heard of Hluvuku from a neighbor. This is her first loan in the amount of 15.000,00MT (U$525) which she'll use to buy more food products (rice, flour, cooking oil and others) to satisfy the demand and attract more customers. She's committed to pay the loan back on time so she can make other loans in the future and improve her business even more.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products for reselling

loans.name: Felicita

texts.en:
Felicita is 60 years old and married. She and her husband are living in the village of Baculud Iguig Cagayan, where farming is the major source of income among the residents. The couple was blessed with four children, all of whom are married. Her husband Francis is 60 years old and works as a farmer in their village.

Felicita has owned and managed their store for years. She and her husband are working hard to save for their future needs. Sometimes, her children also help her maintain their hog raising business, especially during weekends since they all have their own families. 

Felicita believes that they can expand their business a lot. She is asking Kiva lenders for a sum amounting to PHP 10,000. She intends to use the money to buy more merchandise for her store in order to meet the demands of her customers.

loans.use: purchasing more merchandise for her store

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina C. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia City. She is 50 years old and married with 2 adult children. To make a living, Rosalina owns runs a "sari-sari" (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products to the community. Rosalina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rosalina joined HSPFI in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Rosalina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing additional products to sell

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios V. shared that “time management is really important in running a business”. She is engaged in a general store business where she sells different products as such biscuits (cookies), canned goods, soft drinks, detergent soap, condiments, and even vegetables and fruit. With her business she is able to help her husband in financing their daily needs as well as the educational needs of their children.

Remedios is married to Pablito who works as a farmer. The couple is blessed with three children namely: Patrick John, 17 years of age, a second year college student; John Paul, 14 years old; and the youngest is Marichu, who is now 11 years old.

Remedios’s general store is situated at her house at Villa Marcos, Ramon. Her income from the store is quite enough for their daily needs but she still wants to expand it, especially since one of her children is now enrolled in the college level of education. In connection with that she is requesting a Php 5,000 loan from Kiva lenders. She knows that the amount will be of great help to her family and to her business as well.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for the expansion of her variety store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
According to Marites R., “Patience and hard work are the best character traits that should be developed when engaged in business." She has a vegetable plantation beside their house and, being a vegetable vendor for almost five years, she has been very hardworking to support her family. She earns Php 200 daily. Aside from that, she also has a laundry business sometimes to generate extra income.

However, Marites’ income is not good enough to provide for their necessities so she decided to obtain a loan of Php 4,000 to have additional capital to improve her vending business.

Marites is married to Gavino R., a farmer. They have three children: Aries, 18, in college level; Ruel, 16, a first-year college student; and Gabriel, 3 years old. They are presently living in the friendly village of Sta. Maria, Alicia, Isabela.

Marites hopes that Kiva lenders will grant her loan immediately, to enable her to have continuous development in her business.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her vegetable vending business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Allan

texts.en:
Allan C. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia City. He is 44 years old. Allan is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Allan sells snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Allan has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Allan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Allan is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Allan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nghiêm's Group

texts.en:
Quý Nghiêm Thị (20201070014) is a 49-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Quý is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Trung Bạn 02 (2).


Quý is married and has three adult children.  To making a living, Quý sells animal feed & farm-related products in the local community.  Quý has been engaged in this business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5.600.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007, Quý joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Quý has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5.152.000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  She is now requesting a new loan of 7.392.000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Quý from SEDA.  Quý plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Nguyễn V. M. (20201070015) is a 27-year-old male who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support his recycling services business.


2.  Nguyễn K. N. (20201070016) is a 39-year-old male who is requesting a 4.256.000 VND loan to support his fishing business.


3.  Trương Thị D. (20201070017) is a 27-year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


4.  Nguyễn Thị H. (20201070018) is a 60-year-old female who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store.


5.  Nguyễn Thị L. (2020010719) is a 28-year-old female who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her business making furniture. 

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Quý Nghiêm Thị (20201070014) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Quý là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Trung Bạn 02 (2).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm thức ăn gia súc & có liên quan đến nông trại trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Quý thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 12 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Quý kiếm được khoảng 5.600.000 VND.  Vào 2007, Quý đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Quý đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.152.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.392.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn V. M. (20201070015) là 27 tuổi nam.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là cung cấp dịch vụ tái chế.


2.  Nguyễn K. N. (20201070016) là 39 tuổi nam.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.256.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


3.  Trương Thị D. (20201070017) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Nguyễn Thị H. (20201070018) là 60 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


5.  Nguyễn Thị L. (2020010719) là 28 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Yudaya

texts.en: Yudaya is a 50-year-old widow with two children between 18 and 25 years old.  One of her children goes to school. She owns a one-room house where she is staying with two people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Yudaya takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals a day.  She incurs additional transport costs to and from shopping in Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She sells to all categories of people but mainly to schoolchildren because she resides near the school. Yudaya owns a canteen in Kawala selling all types of snacks like samosas, biscuits, fried groundnuts, pancakes and popcorn. Yudaya works seven days a week. On average, she receives 50 customers a day. Her business premise is her residence. Yudaya has been in this business for eight years and with MCDT for four years, servicing her eighth loan. She has worked all along with the same group mates. Her monthly expenses include school fees for her child and feeding the family. Yudaya wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of biscuits, cooking oil and wheat flour for frying chapatti and samosas. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to employ three people to assist her.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for her products

loans.name: Tumaini

texts.en: Tumaini L. is a Tanzanian businesswoman. She is married and has three children. One is in primary school and the other two are in secondary school. She has one store where she sells fruits and green vegetables and another where she sells clothes.  Her stores are located in the Kitunda area of Dar es Salaam. She has been in the business for six years and her business income has been used to further capitalize the business and to meet the daily demands of her family. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000 to buy more business goods for her fruit and vegetable store.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her store

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita is a retailer of vegetables and a hog raiser in their village. She is married to Rogelio, a farmer and a carpenter. They are blessed with two children: Randy and Cora. Cora is a Home and Restaurant Management graduate and works in a restaurant in Manila as a waitress. Sometimes her daughter assists them with their financial needs. 

Carmelita dreams that her son will also finish his studies. However, due to lack of financial resources, he was not able to pursue his education.  She is now hoping that her business will improve enough for them to have a more stable source of income.  She is asking for a loan of PHP7,000 that she needs to buy feed for her hog raising business. She sells her hogs after a few months and her profit from this is used for their daily needs.

loans.use: To purchase feed for her hogs

loans.name: Mrs. Rany Vong Village Bank Group

texts.en:
TwenT.-eight people who are all living in Svay village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Rany V. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members and they will each use the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Rany V. is a grocer who owns a grocery store. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it to support her customers’ demands. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy some more grocery goods to support her business. She hopes to increase her profits and to improve her business.

Mrs. Rany V. is 29 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Pao Saphorn, is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) field of land on which he cultivates rice.

All twenT.-eight members are shown in the photo but some of them are blocked from view.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Hog raising is the main source of income for Teresita A.. She is married to Rufino A. Jr. They have four children.  Jonathan is 15 years old and a second-year high school student. Diosa is 11 years old and a grade VI pupil. John Carlo is nine years old and a Grade II pupil and Bea Maurin is four years old. 


Teresita would like to improve their way of living through her business, but due to the high cost of commodities, she does not have enough capital. So she is asking for financial support from the KIVA lenders for the maintenance of her hog raising business. In this regard, she is requesting PHP4,000. She hopes that her loan will be granted to purchase feed for her animals.

loans.use: To buy feed for her hogs

loans.name: Nghiêm's Group

texts.en:
"Quý Nghiêm Thị (20201070014) is a 49 year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Quý is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Trung Bạn 02 (2).


Quý is married and has 3 adult -aged children.  To making a living, Quý owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling animal feed & farm-related products in the local community.  Quý has been engaged in this business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5.600.000 VND a month from these activities.

Quý plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Nguyễn V. M. (20201070015) is a 27 year-old male who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support his business in the services sector providing recycling services.


2.  Nguyễn K. N. (20201070016) is a 39 year-old male who is requesting a 4.256.000 VND loan to support his business in the food sector operating a fishing business.


3.  Trương Thị D. (20201070017) is a 27 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


4.  Nguyễn Thị H. (20201070018) is a 60 year-old female who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.


5.  Nguyễn Thị L. (2020010719) is a 28 year-old female who is requesting a 6.048.000 VND loan to support her business in the manufacturing sector operating a furniture making business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia is a resident of Murong, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Alfredo Jr. but they do not have any children yet.  They aim to improve their status of living to ensure their future. They help each other earn income for their survival and to save for their future. 

Her husband works as a utility person in Bagabag Municipal Office while Amalia buys and sells charcoal in their village.  Since charcoal is in demand in their village, she wants to improve business by having more capital. She would like to borrow a loan of PHP16,000 to buy more sacks of charcoal to sell in their village.  She hopes this will be a great help to improve her small business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is 42 years old and married with three children between 9 and 20 years of age. All her children go to school. She owns a one-room house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Rebecca takes care of additional family members. She incurs additional transport costs to and from buying chicken feed at Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She sells chickens and eggs to all categories of people at retail and at wholesale.  Rebecca works seven days a week. On average, she receives 20 customers a day. Rebecca has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her 20th loan. Her monthly expenses include school fees for her children and feeding the family. Rebecca wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of chicken feed and chicks. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to start selling at wholesale only. She also hopes to own 10,000 chickens.

loans.use: To buy more chicken feed and chicks

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en:
Cecelia C. is from the village of Colonia, Valencia City. She is 53 years old. Cecelia is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Cecelia runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Cecelia has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Cecelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecelia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Cecelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mabongle

texts.en:
E. B. is married with two children. He and his entire family live in a house with three rooms in GTTC Street, Nkwen, Cameroon. E. had to overcome some challenges in life such as ill health, facing difficulties to pay his children's school fees, and the death of his father when he was still young.

E. has an animal feed store business and also sells palm oil and corn.

E. has been a member of GHAPE since 2008. This will be his third loan. He has been quite successful in the past with his business due to the location of his business and his reasonable prices. Also with more experience he is now having good profits from his business.

Part of the profits from this loan will be used to take care of his children, buy necessities for the family and give them good medication whenever they are sick. Emmanual will plough back the rest into his business.

About GHAPE

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works toward the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Animal feed store and sales of palm oil and corn.

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga A. is very determined in handling her business, because she wants to obtain her desired profits. She manages a retail operation, vending rice grain in their village. Her monthly net income is 300 PHP.

Dominga is asking for a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to 6000 PHP to use for her rice grain vending. She wants to expand her business to maintain the improvement of it.

She is happily married to Mr. Bernard Domingo, a farmer. They have two children: Billy Jay, grade three student, and Bernalyn, a preschooler. The family resides at the village of Culalabat, Cauayan City, a rural area.

She hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her loan, for her to have an additional convenience in her business.

loans.use: To help her retail vending of rice grain.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia D. L. is from the village of Batangan, Valencia City. She is 57 years old and widowed. To make a living, Ofelia operates a specialized retail store. Her main source of income comes from selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp in the local community. Ofelia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Ofelia joined HSPFI to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ofelia is requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP which she will use to expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan D. Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note
To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in her seafood business.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Entrepreneur Rehema G. is a married Tanzanian business-woman with two school-aged children.

Rehema runs a food shop, selling varieties of food crop products at Yombo Viyuka ward in Dar es Salam. She purchases her business goods from the wholesale shops at Kariakoo and other shops around and then she sells to retail customers at her shop.

She uses the business income to meet her family’s daily needs, to pay school fees, and for business capitalization.

Rehema needs a loan of 800,000 TZS to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods to sell.

loans.name: Noli Christopher

texts.en:
Noli Christopher V. and his wife are striving hard to overcome the hardships and difficulties in life. Noli is engaged in selling different scrap materials like plastic bottles, old newspapers, metals, plastics and other recyclable materials.

On the other hand, his wife sells different food snacks like rice cake, pancit (noodles), banana and camote cue (fried potato with sugar).

As fruit of their patience and sacrifice, they can earn a net income of 1000 PHP a week which they use for their daily needs and to save for the future of their two year old son. They want him to be successful someday in his chosen profession and have a bright future.

In this regard, they want to improve their small business to earn a higher income. Due to lack of financial capital, Noli is now asking to borrow a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to 8000 PHP to improve their small business.

They hope that lenders will grant their request so they can have a stable source of income.

loans.use: As additional capital in selling scrap materials.

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza is 39 years old and lives with her family in the village of Culalabat, Cauayan City, Isabela. Flordeliza sells fruits and vegetables in their village. Her daily net profit is 300 PHP, which is not sufficient to provide all her family's everyday needs. Her husband helps to earn more income because they have three children to raise. Their eldest child is a first year high school student, their next daughter is currently enrolled in elementary level, and their youngest daughter is two years old.

Flordeliza's desire to earn more income motivated her to request a loan of 5,000 PHP from Kiva lenders to strengthen her business. In this way she hopes to be able to sustain her family's daily needs and obtain her desired profits. She hopes that Kiva lenders will grant her requested loan so that she can generate additional income.

loans.use: As additional capital in her fruit and vegetable business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Hamadi

texts.en: Hamadi H. is a businessman from Dar es Salaam. He is married and has two children. He runs a food shop business in the Kitunda district of Dar es Salaam, and has been in this business for three years. Hamadi purchases goods wholesale and sells them to his customers retail. He is requesting a loan of 600,000 TZS to buy more goods so he can meet rising customer demand.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia S. is 36 years old and has been selling fruit and vegetables for almost five years now. She is married to Ramil, a farmer in their village. They are blessed with three children: Ryan Vincent, 4; Cris Jhon Paul, 3; and the youngest who is just an infant.

Ramil plants vegetables in their fields while Virginia sells their harvested yield. Having a farm where they can harvest vegetables is very important to the couple thus they want to sustain its productivity. For this reason, Virginia is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to 5,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy more vegetable seed and fertilizer so that they can harvest more yield.

loans.use: To purchase vegetable seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam S. is married with one child who is in kindergarten. Mariam is a small businesswoman who sells charcoal at Yombo Vituka in Dar es Salaam. She has been in the business for one year. She purchases charcoal in wholesale direct from the suppliers and sells it to both retail and wholesale customers. Mariam is requesting a loan of 600,000 TZS to buy more charcoal.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Specioza

texts.en:
Specioza is a 35-year-old married mother of five children aged between 3 and 18 years, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. Specioza owns a one-roomed house where she lives with eight people. The family has access to both electricity and piped water.

Specioza sells chickens and eggs to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. She works seven days a week and, on average, receives ten customers a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying chicken feed at Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She has been in this business for seven years and with Kiva partner MCDT for five years. She is now servicing her twentieth loan. Her monthly expenses include school fees for her children and food for her family.

Specioza wants to use this loan to buy more chicks and sacks of chicken feed. She aspires to see her business grow bigger, to start selling wholesale only, and to own 5,000 chickens.

loans.use: To buy more chicks and chicken feed

loans.name: Elmer

texts.en:
Elmer D. is from the village of  Lumbayao , Valencia  City. He is 30 years old. Elmer is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Elmer owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Elmer has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elmer joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elmer has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elmer is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Elmer from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica N. is a widow with seven children. She lives in Ntaghem- Nkwen- Cameroon.  Monica and her entire family are living in a house with three rooms. Monica had to overcome some challenges in life such as ill health, difficulties in paying her children's  school fees and the death of her husband. She has fire wood business and also sells food stuffs in order to earn a living.

This will be Monica sixth loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2003. She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to the location of her business and her reasonable prices.  Also with her experience, Monica is now receiving good profits from her business. Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her children and to buy necessities for the family and the remainder will be ploughed back part into  her business.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its client

loans.use: Buying of fire wood, yams, potatoes, tomatoes

loans.name: Theresia

texts.en: Theresia S. is a married Tanzanian business  woman. She runs a beautiful Salon in the Yombo Makangarawe ward. She has been in the business for six years. The business goods are purchased from the Kariakoo shops and other cosmetics shops nearby. The business income is used to meet her family's daily needs and to pay the school fees for her children. Theresia is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to buy more business goods to meet her customer's demands.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her business

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group
loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
“Do your best and God will do the rest.” This is the principle of life for Rose. She knows that God will help her with her business only if she will do her part as a businesswoman. Rose is 45 years old and married to Rey R., who has been working abroad for 10 years. They have four children. Two of their children are college graduates working in Manila. The last two of her children are still studying in college. Their family lives harmoniously in Barangay San Roque, Enrile, Cagayan. 

Rose has been engaged in the poultry business for two years. She buys dozens of chicks from Tuguegarao City and sells them after 45 days. She is now asking for the support of Kiva lenders for the maintenance of her business. For this, she would like to borrow 7,000 Philippines pesos to purchase more chicks, medicine and a food supply for their growth.

loans.use: Maintenance for her poultry business

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma T. is from the village of Misom in Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Emma is single and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty food products in the community. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month for these activities.

Emma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Emma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional ingredients for cooking. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Emma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for cooking

loans.name: Fitina

texts.en: Fitina S. runs a small business in Tanzania. She is married and has four school-aged children. Fitina runs a fish selling business (fresh and fried) at Yombo Makangarawe in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her fish, both wholesale and retail, direct from the fisherman at Ferry Fish Market. She has been in the business for six years and has built her own residential home from her business income. She is also able to cover her family's daily expenses from the income. Fitina is requesting a loan of TZS600,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy business goods to meet demand.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en: Rosa C. and her husband Antonio C. of Brgy. Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya are working hard to earn a living for their survival and to support the schooling of their four children. For the sake of their children, they endure hardships and difficulties. Their primary income comes from farming: Antonio cultivates their farm lot by planting a variety of vegetables and rice, while Rosa sells fish balls in their village. Rosa earns an average income of PHP800.00 per week, which they use to pay for their daily expenses and for the schooling of their children. However, since their children are now in college they need to earn more income to finance their studies. For this reason, Rosa wants to borrow PHP5,000.00 in additional capital. She would like to use the capital to improve her small business by purchasing more goods to sell in order to gain a higher income.

loans.use: To improve her food vending business

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth S. is from the village of Balanlinao,Plaridel, Mis.Occ.. She is 36 years-old. Lilibeth is married and has four school-aged children. Lilibeth owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lilibeth joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for agricultural supplies. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional pigs to sell . This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lilibeth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support extended members of the her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pigs to sell.

loans.name: Melita

texts.en:
Melita D. is a 55 year-old businesswoman from Malaria, Caloocan City. She has been a widow for years and now lives with her three children, all of whom are already working and earning for themselves. Melita has been direct-selling beauty parlor supplies and salon products for many years. She is earning more than P 40,000.00 a month.

Melita has been with Kiva partner the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for two years now and has been enjoying the warm ambience of the weekly gathering of her fellowship group. She is now applying for a loan of P22,000.00 which she will use to purchase additional beauty parlor supplies. She wishes to expand her business by establishing a salon branch in other areas.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through a fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase additional beauty parlor supplies.

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita R. is from the village of Calaran, Calamba, Mis.Occ.. She is 45 years-old and married with two school-aged children. Esterlita owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from being a "sari-sari store" or general store which sells a variety of products such as sugar, rice, canned goods, salt, etc. in the local community. Esterlita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Esterlita joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esterlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional goods for her sari- sari store. Esterlita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional goods for her sari-sari store. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Esterlita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support extended members of the her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods for a sari-sari store.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 29 years old and is married with one child, aged 10 years, who goes to school. Mary resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she lives with four people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees for her child and feeding the family.

Mary has a shop dealing in all women’s designer clothes. On average she receives ten customers a day and sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. She buys her clothing materials from Kampala city shops and incurs additional transport costs to and from buying. After a booking for a particular material Mary works seven days a week.

Mary has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for eight years. She is servicing her twentieth loan and wants to use this loan to buy more clothing materials.

Mary is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and to start a designing school.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials for making clothes

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth H. is a Tanzanian married woman and a small-business entrepreneur. She runs a business selling a variety of fruits and vegetables at Makangarawe ward in Dar es Salaam.

Elizabeth purchases her goods from the city fruit market at Buguruni and sells to retail customers at her shop. Her business goods include: bananas, apples, oranges, mangoes and pineapples. She manages to meet her family’s daily demands and the capitalization of the business from her business incomes.

Elizabeth is requesting a loan of Tshs 600,000 to buy more produce to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia S. is from the village of Sto. Niño,Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 41 years old. Alicia is married and has 1 adult-aged child. To make a living, Alicia owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized "sari-sari" retail store. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Alicia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Alicia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alicia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to expand the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Alicia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand business

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Chiabi

texts.en:
C. is married with five children and lives in P.MI Nkwen, a quarter in Bamenda, Cameroon. She will invest her loan in her cosmetics business. She is a very hard working lady, and is literate but unemployed. She lost her father at a tender age which still disturbs her. Being unemployed by the government, she switched to the cosmetics business which has given her some minimal profit to take care of her family. She plans to invest her loan in increasing her cosmetics business.

This is C.'s third loan; she has been a member since 2007. This loan will help her cosmetics business to succeed because she will be able increase her items. She will also be able to purchase original make-up for beauty. With the profits from this loan, C. will save money for future use. She will also pay her children and ensure that they are well prepared for school. Her training in business management that she received from GHAPE will help her to invest this loan in the most efficient and productive manner.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetic products

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn is 27 years old and she is married to Felix O.. The couple has been blessed with three children: Angelica - 12 years old who is in 1st year high school; Cristine Joy - 10 years old who is now a grade-IV pupil; and Felix Jr. - 6 years old.

Arlyn sells fruit and at the same time she also manages their passenger motorcycle. She is busy vending some fruit while her husband is busy cultivating their rice fields.

According to Arlyn, she would like to have a better living but she said that she couldn’t make it because she doesn’t have enough capital for her business. For this reason she would like to borrow capital of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders. This amount will really help her in fulfilling her dreams in life so she hopes that her request will be granted.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for business development

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en: Nelson N. is a Tanzanian small-businessman. He runs a business selling broilers to customers. He purchases from the nearby villages in various Tanzanian regions and transports and sells at Dar es Salaam Market. Local broilers are highly demanded in hotels and for domestic use. Thus, the market is high. His business plan is to open up a big business and be a big supplier. He has been in this business for three years. He needs a loan of TSHS 600,000 to meet his customer's demands.

loans.use: To increase his business

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon M. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur.  He is married with four children who go to school.  He runs a poultry farm in the Kitunda area of Dar es Salaam. He has 2,000 layers in his poultry cages and he collects 20 trays of eggs per day. Over the years, with the money he has generated from his business, he has been able to build his own house and send his children to school. He has already expanded to three poultry cages, but needs another loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to construct more cages and buy more poultry chicks.

loans.use: To buy more cages and chicks
