loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is a 48-year-old single mother of four children between the ages of 15 and 20 years. All her children go to school. She owns a three-room house where she is staying with six people. Rose takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water.  She incurs additional transport costs to and from Nakawa market to buy bananas. She has a stall selling bananas to all categories of people. Rose works seven days a week. On average, she receives two customers a day. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her 10th loan. Her monthly expenses include school fees for her children and feeding the family. Rose hopes to see her business grow stronger and she hope to buy directly from the farmers.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Emilda

texts.en:
Emilda C. is from the village of Magcamiguing, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Emilda is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Emilda operates a specialized retail store, harvesting fruits for sale. Emilda has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

Emilda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emilda is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fruits for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Emilda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units, with offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fruits for sale

loans.name: Elmira's Group

texts.en:
Elmira, a 42-year-old woman, is the leader of this group. Elmira and her husband are raising three children. Their eldest son is 19.  He has already got on his feet and he lives and works in Bishkek. The middle son is a college student. And the little daughter goes to elementary school. Elmira and her husband always strive to give their children a good upbringing, so that their children grow up hardworking and diligent. To provide for the family and pay for the children’s education, Elmira’s husband works as a builder. As for Elmira, she manufactures traditional handicrafts. She wants to get herself a spot at the market and start selling the articles at the market. She got this idea after consulting her relatives, who believe in Elmira’s skill and the profitability of this business. When Elmira first started sewing national articles, she invested 350$. Her expense was worth it, as in a very short time Elmira began receiving orders. Her success has encouraged her to expand her business and start selling the articles in a shop. Since then, she has been nurturing this idea in her soul and making preparations. Now everything is ready. She just needs some funds to purchase fabric. Therefore, Elmira has applied for this loan to start her business, steadily grow and become an independent entrepreneur. She also says that this business would let her give a better education to her daughter.

Elmira’s partners are Batima, Cholponbai and Elnura.

Batima, 46, is divorced. She is a mother of five children. Only her little daughter and son live with Batima. For a living, Batima sells potatoes. She hopes to obtain this loan and invest it in purchasing potatoes. 

Cholponbai, 23, married very early and now has a six-year old son. His wife trades in socks at the market. Cholponbai trades in cattle. He needs a loan to invest in increasing the turnover.

Elnura, 25, is single. After graduating from college, Elnura decided to start trading in cattle. Now, she has a stable income and needs a loan to purchase calves.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Eveline

texts.en:
Eveline is married to Frank Peter and they have four children. She and her entire family are living in a house with five bedrooms. She is a very hard-working woman and has encountered some expenses in the family, such as the death of family members. 

She runs a scotch-egg selling business and a farming business with the support of her children and her changed husband. She will invest the loan in buying eggs, flour and seedlings for farming. With the previous loans she succeeded in providing her community with white stuff (a drink of white liquid from raffia palms) for their social activities. 

This will be her third loan from GHAPE, which she joined in 2007. She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to her location in the school campus (progressive college), the quality of her food and her reasonable prices. She has a strong customer base and is confident that she will be able to increase her sales. 
 
Part of the profits from this loan will be used for the school fees of her children. And the other part will be used to buy a plot of land. Eveline does not foresee a problem with her loan repayments. She intends to start repayment in the fourth month after taking the loan. 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works toward the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buy eggs, groundnut oil, flour

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
This is Olivia C., who is 51 years old. Her husband, Salvador, 50, is a construction foreman. They have nine children: four are now working and earning; two are still in college; two are in high school and the youngest is in grade school. They live in Camarin, Caloocan City.

For 15 years now, Olivia’s general store has proved to be a good source of additional income for her large family. She was able to send her children to school out of her earnings. She now makes 5,700 Philippine pesos a month and her store continues to provide basic services to her neighbors.

She came to know the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative three years ago and is now on her 12th loan cycle. She has applied for a new loan in the amount of 12,000 PHP as additional capital for her general store.  

She dreams of having a larger grocery store someday.  

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social-development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Donasia

texts.en: Donasia A. is a married Tanzanian entrepreneur with one child. She runs a business of selling charcoal at Tabata in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the charcoal directly from the manufacturers wholesale and sells it to retail customers at her business yard. Charcoal is the main source of domestic power in most of the developing countries, although it is much more environmentally destructive. She has been in the business for three years. She is requesting a loan of 600,000 Tanzanian shillings to buy more business goods to meet her customers' demand.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie L. is a 43 year old store owner from Ascoville, Malaria, Caloocan City. Her husband Henry, also 43, is a welder working for an auto repair shop. They have two children; one is in college and the other in high school. Rosemarie started her general store five years ago and it has been growing through the years. She also sells electronic load credits for mobile phones. Aside from her husband’s income, her own income from her business helps her send their children to school. She earns P9,000.00 per month from her business. 

Rosemarie became aware of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005 and eventually became one of its satisfied members. She has applied for a new loan in the amount of P12, 000.00 as additional capital for her general store. She dreams of having a larger grocery store someday.  

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To acquire additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en: Vicky is 42 years old and married with six children between the ages of eight and 27 years. Four of her children go to school. Vicky resides and rents a two bedroom house where she stays with five people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water at home. Vicky sells bitengi (African wears) and jewelry from the Democratic Republic Of Congo, which is her home country. Working seven days a week, Vicky sells to customers from all walks of life. On average she receives 25 customers per day. She has been in this business for seven years, working with the same group of people. Vicky has also been with MCDT for seven years and is servicing her fourteenth loan. She decided to join MCDT because it was near her home and also because she could obtain timely loans. Vicky would like to use this loan to buy more bitengi and jewelry. She aspires to see her business grow larger and to start selling exclusively on the wholesale market.

loans.use: To buy more jewerly and African wears.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita D. is a 48 year old single mother. She lives with her two children, who are both enrolled in college, in Malaria, Caloocan City. Teresita has been in business for the last 18 years. She started small, just like any other entrepreneur, but her hard work and perseverance paid off. Her general store now qualifies to be called a mini-grocery store. Life, however, took a turn on her, her husband passed away a few years back but she didn’t lose hope. She worked hard to sustain their basic daily needs by focusing on her business.  Thanks to her faith, she was able to cope. Her monthly income is now P27, 000.00.
 
She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005. She has been active in inviting other women in her community to her group. She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative. Teresita is now on her tenth loan cycle and she has applied for a fresh loan in the amount of P50, 000.00. She dreams of having a larger grocery store someday and possible another branch.  

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To expand her grocery business

loans.name: Hamis

texts.en:
Hamis O. is a Tanzanian married man, an entrepreneur and a businessman. He runs a shop at Buguruni in Dar es Salaam, buying and selling varieties of foodstuffs such as wheat flour, maize flour, beans, groundnuts (peanuts), cooking oil and sugar. He purchases in wholesale from the wholesale shops and sells to his retail customers at Buguruni. He has been in the business for three years and the business income enables him to meet his family’s daily demands.

Hamis is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000 to boost his business.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for his store

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: This is Linda B., a 46-year-old store owner from Tala, Caloocan City. She has five children, one of whom is in high school and two in grade school. Her husband, Jimmy, 43, is a factory worker. Linda has been in business for six years already. She manages her own sari-sari (general) store located at their house. On a monthly basis, she makes more than P10,000. She saves most of her profits to support the education of her children. In 2007, Linda came to know about the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative and eventually became a member. She enjoys attending its weekly meetings for women entrepreneurs. Linda has applied for a new loan with the cooperative in the amount of P15,000 as additional capital for her store. Linda says she couldn’t ask for more because all her children are responsible in their studies which gives her all the inspiration to work hard in her business. She is thinking of embarking on additional business ventures soon. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: This is Susan H., 43 years old. She has been making processed meats like sausages and hams in the comfort of her home for the last three years. She lives in Ascoville, Caloocan City with her husband, Robert, 60, and their only child. Susan’s products appeal to a lot to her customers so that she always finds herself working overtime to meet their demands. She is thankful to the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative for providing her loans which she has used to buy raw materials like fresh meat and seasonings. She now earns at least P6,000 a month, aside from her additional income being a tutor in the neighborhood. She has a teacher’s education back in college. Susan uses her profits to support the daily needs of her family. She applied for a fresh loan from CCT in the amount of P8,000 as additional capital for her business. She also wishes to establish a restaurant soon. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Patricial

texts.en:
Patricial has a grocery stall at the front of her house where she sells groceries at retail prices to her customers in Asaba, Delta State. Her greatest joy is the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She has been in this business for a long time.

Patricial is married with four children and she is 48 years old. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Goodluck

texts.en:
Goodluck M. is an entrepreneurial Tanzanian businessman. He is a married man with five children of whom three are in primary school and one is in secondary school.

Goodluck runs a garden at Kitunda community in Dar es Salaam. He grows a variety of green vegetables and fruits and sells them at Kariakoo city market to retail customers. He has been in the business for nine years and has managed to buy a water pump machine. The business income helps him to meet his children's school fees and his daily family demands.

Goodluck is requesting a loan of Tshs 600,000 to expand his business.

loans.use: To use for business expansion

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en:
Augustine is a commercial motorcyclist. He is 32 years old and married with a child. He conveys his passengers from one location to another in Asaba, Delta State. He has been in his business since 2006. He renders these services to enable him to put food on the table for his immediate family members.

Augustine hopes to be a big transporter in the future. He wants to hire another person to join him in his business so that he can convey more passengers. He is requesting a loan of 80,000 naira to purchase a motorcycle to enable him to convey more passengers from one location to another.

Augustine says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen has a retail shop selling home products to all kinds of people. She is a 50-year-old married woman with four children between the ages of 24 and 34 years. Helen also takes care of additional family members. None of her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she lives with four people. Her family has access to electricity and piped water.

Helen works seven days a week. She serves an average of 25 customers a day. She buys her merchandise from Nakawa market and incurs extra transport costs to and from her suppliers using public transportation. Her monthly challenges include rent for her business and residence, school fees and medication. She has been in her business for 20 years and with MCDT for four years – now on her tenth loan working with the same group mates. Helen joined MCDT because it is near her home. She hopes to see her business grow and to own a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise like sugar, salt, soap and cooking oil

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha sells groceries and baby things at the front of her house in Asaba, Delta State. She is married with six children and she is 45 years old. She is a hardworking woman and she hopes to lift her family out of poverty. She has been in her business for a long time. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 naira to purchase more groceries and baby things to sell.

Martha says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and baby things to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To upgrade computer units

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity sells food at the market in Asaba, Delta State. She has been in this business for a long time, and is a focused, hard worker. This is the high season for her sales and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. Charity is 32 years old and married with 5 children. Charity's four eldest children are all in school. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more food to sell, and thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase food merchandise

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 43 years old and is married with five children. She sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers in Asaba, Delta State.

Elizabeth is a hardworking woman and she is very determined to lift her business and family above poverty. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Mwanahamis

texts.en:
Mwanahamis B. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur. She is a married woman with four school-aged children of whom three are in secondary school and one is in primary school.

Mwanahamis runs two groceries at Tabata community in Dar es Salaam. She sells a variety of both soft and alcoholic drinks. She has been in the business for six years and, with her business income, she has managed to pay school fees, meet daily family demands and also capitalize the business.

Mwanahamis finished repaying 1,200,000 Tshs and she is requesting a new loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to boost her business.

loans.use: To use for business expansion

loans.name: Khasay

texts.en:
Khasay M. is a responsible father of three children. From the time he was a boy, he learned the honorable work of raising livestock, activities which were passed down from his parents and which today bring him satisfaction. Thanks to his valuable knowledge of the livestock trade, he has been able to obtain good results from his sales. 

This enterprising gentleman’s wish is to invest more capital in young animals. Khasay hopes to continue his dedication to his work, believing that by improving his stock and feed, his cattle will bring better prices. For this reason, he is turning to you for the support that would permit him to continue developing his business.

loans.use: Purchase three cattle and fodder

loans.name: Mahammad

texts.en:
Mahammad M. is a very courageous man who is characterized as someone who can manage tough jobs like raising cattle and agriculture. He's the father of three children and has the responsibility of supporting his family and providing them with everything that they need. In spite of his difficult economic situation and after much time, he has been able to get ahead in his business through the purchase of cattle to breed them on his property. 

His greatest goal nowadays is to improve his economic situation and provide a better way of life for his family. It's for this reason that Mahammad applied for 1606 AZN to buy animals so that he may breed them.

loans.use: Purchase three cattle and fodder

loans.name: Begbuta

texts.en:
E. Begbuta works in agriculture and has always been efficient in his labors. He has been growing potatoes and onions for 10 years. He is 40 years old and married with four children. The role of father, which he has carried out for 15 years, has helped him to understand the sacrifice and hard labor of the women of the house. Now Begbuta wants to build a greenhouse but he lacks capital. He wants to borrow 3,500 somoni so he can buy potato and onion bags. He will also use part of the loan to construct a greenhouse. When the season ends, Begbuta wants to sell potatoes in bags for a good price.

This request is in support of improving his living conditions and Begbuta is asking for help from your generous heart.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase bags for potatos and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty M. S. is a small business owner. She runs a poultry business in Tabata community, Dar es Salaam. She has 800 layers in her poultry cages. She collects ten trays of eggs per day and sells both wholesale and retail. Betty is a married woman with four school children. One is in kindergarten, two are in primary school and one is in secondary school. She meets her daily family demands and pays school fees with her business income. She plans to increase the size of her business by buying more poultry chicks. She needs a loan of 800,000 Tanzanian shillings to boost up the business.

loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Selina

texts.en: Selina A. is a small business owner. She runs a cosmetics shop in Tabata ward, Dar es Salaam. She is a married woman with two school-age children. Both are in primary school. She has been in her business for one year. She plans to open a big cosmetics shop but capital is a limiting factor. She needs a loan of 800,000 Tanzanian shillings to expand the business.

loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Balimaya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe  BALIMAYA sont toutes mariées dans des familles  monogames avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et 2 enfants. Elles habitent à MEDINE, un des  quartiers de la ville de Sikasso  3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur  huitième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but  de  satisfaire le besoin de la  clientèle et d’augmenter leurs profits. Tous les prêts précédents  se sont dénoués. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente d’oignon,  de produits de beauté, d’habits pour enfant etc. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 200  kg d’oignon, 30 cartons de produits de beauté et 25 colis d’habits pour enfants.  Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso, Bamako et dans les villages environnants. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place, à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18 000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour  rembourser le prêt et l’autre partie servira d’épargne pour subvenir au problèmes de santé.
Les femmes du groupe Balimaya  ambitionnent de bénéficier d’un prêt plus important pour agrandir leurs activités.
texts.en:
The four women of the group BALIMAYA are all married, in monogamous families, and average 37 years of age and 2 children each. They live in MEDINE, a district of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are on their eighth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of increasing their profits and meeting customer needs. All the previous loans have been settled. The group members run diverse businesses, including selling onions, beauty products, and clothing for children. With this new loan, they intend to buy 200 kg of onions, 30 boxes of beauty products, and 25 packets of children’s clothing. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City, from Bamako, and from surrounding villages. Sales are made in cash to customers composed of women and men at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City, at the house, and by going door-to-door. They each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 18,000 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be used to repay the loan, and the other portion will go into savings for covering health problems. The women of the group have the ambition to obtain a bigger loan for expanding their businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 45 years old and married, with five children between 16 and 25 years of age.  All of her children attend school. Rose also takes care of additional family members.

She owns a two-room house where she stays with seven people.  Her family has access to electricity and piped water.

Rose has a restaurant, where she works seven days a week, with an average of 25 customers a day.  She buys the food for the restaurant from Kalerwe Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala.  She incurs additional transport costs traveling to and from the market.

Her major business challenges include thieves and the rainy season. Rose's monthly expenses include rent for her business and residence, school fees and medication.  She has been in this business for 30 years.  She has been a member of MCDT for four years. This is her twelfth loan working with the same group mates. Rose joined MCDT because it was near her home and also to increase her capital. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a hotel.

loans.use: To buy food such as bananas, potatoes, sweet potatoes

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe  DANAYA  sont toutes mariées dans des familles  monogames avec une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et  2 enfants. Elles habitent à MEDINE un des  quartiers de la ville de Sikasso  3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur  huitième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but  de  satisfaire le besoin de leur  clientèle et d’augmenter leur profit. Tous  les prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de tissus, d’habits,la restauration, la vente tubercules (pomme de terre, igname) etc. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter,  20 pagnes wax , 20 colis de tissus pour enfants, 15 sacs de pomme de terre et 200 kg d’igname. 
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso, Bamako et dans les villages environnants. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place, à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour aider le mari et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe DANAYA  ambitionnent de devenir des commerçantes grossistes.
texts.en:
The four women of the DANAYA group are all married and in monogamous families. On average they are 38 years of age and have 2 children. They live in MEDINE, one of the neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso, 3rd administrative region of Mali. They are on their eighth loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, with the intention of satisfying the needs of their clientele and increasing their profit. All the preceding loans were repaid well. They perform various activities, including the sale of fabrics and clothing, restoration and the sale of root vegetables (potato, yam, etc.), among others. With this new loan, they plan to buy, 20 sheets of wax, 20 packages of fabrics for children, 15 bags of potatos and 200 kg of yams. They supply themselves in the big market of the city of Sikasso, Bamako and in the surrounding towns. The merchandise is sold from a location in the big market of Sikasso city, door-to-door and on foot to a cash clientele composed of both women and men. They hope to realize an average monthly profit of 18,000 FCFA each, of which a part will be used to help their husbands and the rest will be invested in the business and in repaying the loan. The women of the DANAYA group aim to become wholesale traders.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy potatos, yams, cloth, wax and other items for resale

loans.name: Jeremiah Asala

texts.en:
Jeremiah runs a computer-service shop on the outskirts of the town of Kakamega.  His shop is located in a busy building near a highway along Kakamega-Webuye road.  This location is good for his clients as it offers easy access to his services.

Jeremiah's major clients are local schools, colleges and computer dealers.  His business challenge is the long credit period needed by his clients.  Jeremiah is seeking a loan of KES20,000 to buy a printer and introduce internet service at his business in order to improve his cash flow.  

Jeremiah is married and has been blessed with two daughters.  In the next five years, he wants to improve his family's standard of living and to make his business stable.  He describes himself as the best provider of computer services in Kakamega.

loans.use: Buy a printer and introduce internet services.

loans.name: Sinjiya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe  SINJIYA  sont toutes mariées dans des familles  monogames avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent à MEDINE  un des  quartiers de la ville de Sikasso  3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur  quatrième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but  de  satisfaire le besoin de leur  clientèle et d’augmenter leur profit. Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés sans aucune difficulté.
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente du bois de chauffe, d’orange, et de pomme de terre. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter,  30 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe , 15 sacs d’orange et 20 sacs de pomme de terre.  
Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et dans les villages environnants. Les marchandises sont vendues au grand marché de Sikasso ville  sur place, à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant et souvent à crédit.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 19 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour aider le mari et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe SINJIYA  ambitionnent de devenir des commerçantes grossistes.
texts.en:
The four women of the SINJIYA group are all married and in monogamous families. On average they are 39 years of age and have 3 children. They live in MEDINE, one of the neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso, 3rd administrative region of Mali. They are on their fourth loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, with the intention of satisfying the needs of their clientele and increasing their profits. All the preceding loans were reimbursed without any difficulty. They perform various activities including the sale of wood for heating, oranges, and potatoes. With this loan, they plan to buy 30 loads of firewood, 15 bags of oranges and 20 bags of potatoes. They supply themselves in the big market of the city of Sikasso and in the surrounding towns. The merchandise is sold from a location in the big market of Sikasso city, door-to-door and on foot to a clientele composed of women and men, for cash and often for credit. They hope to realize an average monthly profit of 19,000 FCFA each, of which a part will be used to help their husbands and the remainder will be invested in the business and in repaying the loan. The women of the SINJIYA group aim to become wholesale traders.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood, oranges and potatoes for resale

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Danaya est un regroupement de quatre femmes qui vivent dans des ménages polygames traditionnels. Elles ont en moyenne 48 ans, 6 enfants et habitent  dans quartier Bamanan Kin (Diamarabougou) de Markala (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle des femmes du quartier. Cette association, fut encadrée par l’ONG ROCAM II dans le cadre de ses formations en teinture, alphabétisation, assainissement etc. 
Ces femmes du groupe Danaya font comme activités  le commerce d’articles divers et ont adhéré à Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leurs clientèles. 
Après quatre prêt solidaires tous correctement remboursés, elles sont à leur 5ème  prêt de groupe qu’elles comptent utiliser pour acheter, 10 pièces de pagnes wax, 10 pièces de tissus, six  tenues brodées,  2 sacs de sucre, 20 kg de gingembre, 1panier de citron, 1panier de tamarin, 1 colis  de poudre de pain de singe, 1paquet de poudre de jus de fruits, 1paquet d’essences aromatisées, 68 chargements de charrettes en bois. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  en pagnes wax et en tissus une fois par mois à Bamako  et  quelques rares fois  au grand marché de Ségou, en sucre et ingrédients pour la préparation de jus locaux sur place à la foire hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou Markala, hebdomadairement en bois de chauffe à Sarkala. La vente se fait sur place à domicile ou en ambulant, au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 71.000 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire certaines charges de la famille, aux petits besoins personnels, au remboursement des intérêts du prêt et  à participer aux évènements sociaux.
Leurs ambitions sont : avoir un moyen de transport du bois de chauffe, épargner petit à petit afin d’avoir  une maison à usage  d’habitation propre à eux et à leurs enfants.
texts.en:
Danaya is a group of four women that live in traditional polygamous households. On average, they are 48 years of age and have 6 children. They live in the Bamanan Kin (Diamarabougou) neighborhood of Markala (4th administrative Region of the republic of Mali). They know each other through bonds of neighborhood and of membership to the same traditional association of women of the neighborhood. This association was formed by the NGO ROCAM II as part of their efforts to train in the dyeing of cloth, literacy, sanitation, etc. These women of the Danaya group work selling various items and approached Soro Yiriwaso in the interest of satisfying the needs of their clientele. After four successfully repaid loans, they are on their 5th group loan, which they plan to use to buy 10 pieces of wax for making batik cloth, 10 pieces of fabrics, six skeins of embroidery thread, 2 bags of sugar, 20 kg of ginger, 1 crate of lemons, 1 crate of tamarinds, 1 package of powdered baobab fruit, 1 package of powdered fruit juice, 1 package of flavored sodas and 68 loads of firewood. They supply themselves in wax and in fabrics once a month in Bamako and occasionally in the big market of Ségou. They buy sugar and ingredients for the preparation of local juices at the weekly market in Diamarabougou Markala and they buy firewood weekly at the market in Sarkala. Their sales are made door-to-door or on foot, for cash and for credit to a clientele composed of women and men. They hope to realize a monthly average profit of 71,000 FCFA that will serve to satisfy certain family expenses, cover their small personal needs, repay the loan and permit them to participate in social events. Their ambitions are to have a means of transportation for the firewood and to save little by little in order to have a house of their own for themselves and their children.

Translated from French by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy wax, fabrics, firewood, fruits, sugar, etc for resale

loans.name: Djiguissèmè Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguissèmè est composé de huit femmes mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygames élargies avec en moyenne 42 ans, 5 enfants et habitant le quartier Service Kin (Diamarabougou) de Markala (4ème Région administrative  de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et d’appartenance à même  association traditionnelle des femmes du quartier.  Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, les draps de lit, les pagnes wax, la couture,  du poisson, la fabrication des boissons non alcoolisées, du bois de chauffe, du charbon de bois,  des céréales etc.
Après quatre prêts solidaires, tous correctement remboursés, elles sont à leur cinquième  qui sera  utilisé pour acheter, 21 pièces de pagnes wax, 50 pièces de popeline, 5 rouleaux de files à broder, 20 sacs de riz, 8 sacs de haricot, 30 kg de gingembre, 5 seaux de citron, 2 sacs de sucre, 5 paquets d’essences aromatisées, 20  chargements de charrettes en bois de bois et 30 sacs de charbon de bois. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  en pagnes wax et en tissus une fois par mois à Bamako et  quelques rares fois  au grand marché de Ségou, en céréales à Boussin, Dougabougou et Katièna, en poisson au bord du fleuve Niger à Markala, en ingrédients pour la préparation de jus locaux sur place à la foire hebdomadaire de Diamarabougou Markala, en bois de chauffe et en charbon de bois à Sarakala. 
La vente se fait sur place à domicile ou en ambulant  au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel de 60.000 FCFA qui servira à satisfaire certaines charges de la famille (savon, prix de condiments et habillement), à payer les fournitures scolaires des enfants et à rembourser les intérêts du prêt. 
Elles ont pour ambitions d’assurer l’éducation de leurs enfants, l’achat des matériels agricoles et de machines à coudre.
texts.en:
Group Djiguisseme is made up of eight married women in mostly big polygamous extended families who average 42 years of age, five children and live in the Service Kin( Diamarabougou) neighborhood of Markala ( fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They knew each other through neighborhood relationship and membership in the same traditionnal women's association of the neighborhood. This women's group trade in various items such as bed sheets, wax fabrics, dressmaking, fish, making of non alcoholic drinks, firewood, cereals etc. After four group loans, all repaid correctly, they are on their fifth loan which will be used to buy 21 pieces of wax fabrics, 50 pieces of poplin, 5 rolls of embroidery floss, 20 bags of rice, 8 bags of beans, 30kg of ginger, 5 buckets of lemon, 2 bags of sugar, 5 packets of flavoured species, 20 loads of wooden carts of wood, and 30 bags of charcoal. They get their supplies of wax cloth and materials once a month in Bamako and a few times in the big Segou market, cereals in Boussin, Dougabougou and Ketiena, fish by River Niger in Markala, ingredients for the preparation of local juice right in the weekly market of Diamarabougou Markala, firewood and charcoal at Sarakala. They sell right at home or by door-to-door for cash or for credit to a clientele made of women and men. They hope to make an average monthly profit of 60 000FCFA which will be used to meet some expenses of their families ( soap, buying of ingredients and clothes), to pay for children's school supplies and to repay the interest of the loan. Their aim is to ensure the education of their children, the purchase of agricultural equipment and sewing machines.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Boturjon

texts.en:
Boturjon is 36 years old. He is married and has two independent children. Boturjon is a farmer. He has been working in agriculture for 4 years and has gained much experience and a love for the land. He began cultivating his land through his own efforts and has gradually gotten ahead in life. He has been producing such crops as wheat, onion, potatoes. Each year he has produced a yield sufficient for the family consumption and for selling. 

Farming is the family's main source of income.  To generate a stable income, the business requires considerable funding. Boturjon is asking for a loan of $1000 USD. He would like to use this loan to buy supplies for the harvest and to improve production and thus increase the quality of his yield along with his earnings. Boturjon and his family are counting on your help. He thanks all who support him and promises to repay the loan in time.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame  Mariam Koné est âgée de 35 ans, mariée et mère  de 3  enfants.  Elle  vit avec son mari et ses enfants dans une famille traditionnelle avec plusieurs autres ménages dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville  de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Mariam n’a pas fréquenté l’école moderne, elle fréquenta plutôt la medersa qu’elle abandonna  en classe de 7ème année (système éducatif Malien) pour apprendre le métier tailleur. Elle  commença  auprès d’un maître tailleur, après avoir fait 5 ans d’apprentissage et riche de cette expérience empirique, elle évolue seule et mène cette activité depuis 10 ans. Elle jouit d’une grande notoriété et clientèle. Sa force de vente est due à son enthousiasme, surtout à sa ponctualité sur le délai de livraison. En plus du métier de tailleur, elle fait de la teinture.
Dans le souci  d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices. Elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est  à son 1er prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser  pour acheter une machine à coudre de marque CORNA. Elle s’approvisionne sur place. Madame  Mariam Koné vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permet d’aider son mari et de participer aux événements sociaux (baptême, mariage etc.…). 
Son ambition est d’ouvrir une boutique de prêt-à-porter.
texts.en:
Ms. Mariam Koné is 35 years old, married, and the mother of three children. She lives with her husband and children in a traditional family with several other families in the Hamdallaye district of the city of Ségou (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mariam didn’t have modern schooling. Rather, she went to a medersa, which she quit in the 7th year (education system of Mali) in order to learn tailoring. She started off with a master tailor. After five years of apprenticeship, she is rich with practical experience, and she is advancing on her own and has been running this business for ten years now. She enjoys a good deal of distinction and a large customer base. Her selling power is due to her enthusiasm, especially her punctuality in fulfilling orders. In addition to her tailoring trade, she dyes cloth. Concerned about increasing her business capital in order to realize more profits, she turned toward Soro Yiriwaso. She is on her first individual loan, which she intends to use to buy a CORNA brand sewing machine. Her supplies are gotten locally. And sales are made in cash or on credit to customers composed of women and men. With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA. This profit allows her to help her husband and to assist with societal events (baptisms, marriages, etc.) Her ambition is to open a ready-to-wear clothing store.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Zafar

texts.en:
R. Zafar is 23 years old. He is married and has one child. Zafar is the main breadwinner in the family.

For more than 8 years, Zafar has been baking the national bread “lepeshka”. He believes that this business is profitable and is not subject to seasonality. He gets up early and bakes lepeshka and bread so that people have fresh bread on their tables for breakfast. All the input materials like the flour, salt, yeast he is purchasing in the local market.

Now Zafar requests 4000 Somoni that he will spend to purchase the flour and coal for baking the “lepeshka”. Zafar deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing flour for baking of the national bread “lepeshka”.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma is into a fish selling business. She is a 52-year-old single parent of four children. All of her children are currently out of senior high school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in the town of Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Though a commercial town, the majority of the inhabitants practice farming as a hobby or major occupation alongside other trading activities. Emma buys smoked fish from nearby fishing communities. She hawks them in her community and also sells at the local market. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy smoked fish

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr: Mamadou T. est un sociétaire de la caisse de Ouakam.Il a choisi l’activité de commerce par amour .Il capitalise une expérience de un mois dans la gestion de sa boutique. Il est marie et père de trois enfants dont l’âge varie entre 3 et 7ans. Sa femme est vendeuse de café touba.Généralement de 7h du matin jusqu'à 00h il vaque a ses occupations de commerçant.Il est parvenu a épargner un fond qui lui a permis de démarrer les activités de sa boutique. Il assure mensuellement un revenu qui varie entre 300 000 et 400 000frs, mais il prévoit de les doubler après son financement. Il sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs pour augmenter son fond de roulement et diversifier ses produits et services par l’achat de sacs d’oignons et de pommes de terre. Son souhait est de maximiser ses bénéfices-
texts.en:
Mamadou T. is a member of the branch office of Ouakam. He chose work in commerce for the love of it. He capitalizes on a month of experience in managing his store. He is married and the father of three children, aged 3 to 7 years. His wife is a seller of café touba. Generally, from 7:00 AM until midnight, he is busy with his work in commerce. He managed to save funds enabling him to start operating his store. In monthly revenues, he makes from 300,000 to 400,000 francs. But he anticipates doubling this after his financing. He’s requesting a loan of 100,000 francs to increase his working capital and to diversify his products and services by purchasing sacks of onions and potatoes. He wishes to maximize his profits.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Homid

texts.en:
Homid is a hardworking entrepreneur from Istaravshan, Tajikistan. He has operated his own car repair business for the past 10 years. Homid has extensive experience in this field and his skills are very much in demand. Car ownership is increasing rapidly in Tajikistan which means more business for repair technicians like Homid. Homid works hard to earn a good income and support his family. He and his wife have three children. Homid has requested a loan of $1500 US to expand his workshop. He is very thankful to everyone who has decided to support him.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To expanding his workshop

loans.name: Tatia

texts.fr:
Madame  Tatia  Koné est âgée de 22 ans, mariée et mère  de 2  enfants.  Elle  vit avec son mari et ses enfants en location avec plusieurs autres ménages au quartier Missira  de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne par refus de son père, un fervent traditionaliste qui voulait qu’elle fasse plutôt l’école coranique. Tatia est issue d’une famille de commerçants, d’un père colporteur de cola et d’une mère qui vendait une boutique d’articles divers. Elle  commença  alors très tôt le commerce auprès de sa mère, et cela pendant plusieurs années. Elle a  acquis ainsi de solides expériences dans le commerce. C’est alors qu’elle décida d’évoluer seule, en embrassant le commerce de  la friperie (d’habits, de chaussures,  de soutien gorge etc.) Depuis  3 ans elle jouit d’une grande clientèle. 
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 12 mois, après 1er prêt individuel correctement bien remboursé, elle est à son 2ème prêt qu’elle compte utiliser  pour acheter, 5 balles de friperies. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako et au Burkina Faso. Madame   Tatia  Koné vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permet de s’habiller, de payer des ustensiles de cuisine et d’aider son mari dans la prise en  charge des dépenses familiales. 
Son ambition est  de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Ms. Tatia Koné is 22 years old, married, and the mother of two children. She is renting with her husband and children and several other families in the Missira district of Ségou (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She didn’t attend modern schools due to her father’s refusal, since he is a fervent traditionalist who wanted her to attend Koran school instead. Tatia is from a family of merchants, with a father peddling cola and a mother who used to sell various goods in a shop. Very early on then, she began working in commerce with her mother for several years. She has thus acquired solid experience in it. And so, she decided to advance on her own by embracing commerce in second-hand clothing (outfits, footwear, brassieres, etc.) For three years, she has enjoyed a large customer base. With plans to increase her business capital, in order to realize more profits, she turned toward Soro Yiriwaso. She has been associated with this micro-finance institution for 12 months. After having properly repaid her first individual loan, she is now on her second loan, which she intends to use to buy five bales of used clothing. Her supplies are gotten in Bamako and from Burkina Faso. Sales are made in cash or on credit to customers composed of women and men. With this loan, she plans on realizing a monthly profit of 60,000 francs CFA. This will enable her to clothe herself, to pay for kitchen utensils, and to help her husband to cover family expenses. Her ambition is to build a house in which to live.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bales of used clothing

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha runs a provisions store by the roadside in her community. She is 45 years old, married and has given birth to three children. All of her children are in school. She lives with her family in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Martha has been in business for some years now and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase her stock. Martha wants to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy provisions

loans.name: Khushbakht

texts.en:
S. Khushbakht is 24 years old. He is married and has two children. Khushbakht has the business of baking “lepeshka”- national bread. Khushbakht is the main breadwinner in the family. He believes that this business is profitable and is not the subject to the seasonality. He wakes early and bakes the lepeshka and bread so that people will have the fresh bread on their tables for breakfast. He purchases all the ingredients, like the flour, salt, yeast at the local market. Now, due to high demands, Khushbakht wants to increase the amount of bread he bakes so that he requests 5000 Somoni. The loan will be spent for purchasing the flour and coal for baking the “lepeshka”. Khushbakht deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing ingredient for national bread “lepeshka”.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is a fifty-six year old mother of four children. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Kade, a farming and commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She tells us that all of her children are out of school. Gladys is a food vendor. She sells rice and stew in the mornings by the roadside in her community. She buys bags of rice and other food items from nearby towns. Gladys has been in business for some years now and wants a loan to buy ingredients in larger quantities.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice.

loans.name: Narzullo

texts.en:
T. Narzullo is 27 years old. He is married and has two children. Narzullo is a market vendor. He has been selling fruit for 9 years. For these years Narzullo has acquired the knowledge and skills required for the business. For instance, he knows how to store the fruit so that it keeps its marketable condition and does not lose taste and useful properties. He sells fruit such as: apple, pear and pomegranate in the local market center. Narzullo buys vegetables and fruit from the local farmers. In the market, he is known among people because of the attractive prices and his friendly characteristics. This allows Narzullo’s business to generate stable and considerable income for his family. Due to the season, Narzullo’s now wants to purchase apples and bags for saving them. He will sell them later when the price will increase. Narzullo thanks everyone for supporting him.

loans.use: Increasing of the range of fruits for sale.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is forty. She is married and has four children, all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works hard to help her husband provide for the family. Grace is a trader. She sells kerosene in gallons and bottles in her community. She says she buys from fuel tankers that come around to supply. Grace sells to retailers in her community. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to buy kerosene in large quantity so she can supply to more customers.

loans.use: To buy kerosene.

loans.name: Nuriddin

texts.en:
Nuriddin is married and has three children. He uses his car to offer taxi services in his city and between neighboring cities as well. Nuriddin has been in this business for 9 years. Using the phone to get client’s orders, he always has plenty of clients. This business is the only source of income for his family. Nuriddin would like to borrow $1500 USD to fix his car engine. As he makes more profit, he hopes to improve his family’s living conditions.

loans.use: Purchasing of spare parts for repairing parts of his car.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is a forty-one year old, married, mother of two children, both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Kade is a commercial town. However, majority of the inhabitants practice farming as a hobby or major occupation alongside other trading activities. Agnes is trader. She trades in maize and other food items such as yams. She buys the goods from nearby communities and sells at the local market. She has been in this business for eleven years and wants a loan to purchase goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize.

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en: Ronald Embelywa owns a Livendi shop where he sells sugar, sodas, bread, flour, sanitary towels and cooking oil to retail customers. He has two employees. His business challenges are inadequate capital and the increasing cost of doing business (e.g business license is expensive). He needs a loan of KES 60,000 to buy tea leaves, sugar and sewing materials. His dream is to build a business empire. Ronald has a housewife with ten children ranging from age two to twenty nine years and describes  himself as hardworking, with a vision.

loans.use: To buy stock of sugar, tea leaves and sewing materials.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is a twenty-nine year old, married, young woman with a son in school. She lives with her child and husband in a rented apartment in a town called Kade, in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Though Kade is a commercial town, majority of the inhabitants are into farming as a hobby or major occupation along side other trading activity. Alice is a trader. She trades in groundnut paste. She buys the fresh groundnut from nearby communities, roasts and sends to the mill to have it milled into paste. Alice sells at the local market and also supplies to food vendors. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy groundnuts in large quantity.

loans.name: Tettey

texts.en: Tettey is forty-three. He is married and has four children, all in school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade in the Eastern Region of Ghana. He works hard to be able to provide for the family. Tettey is a trader. He deals in mobile phones and accessories. He sells in a shop by the roadside in his community. He tells us that he buys the phones from the big cities at affordable prices. Tettey has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure all kinds of phones in larger quantities in order to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy phones and accessories.
